Very juicy bringing up notes of ripe grapes. Sourness is very apparent but not over powering. Carbonation gives the beer a nice prickly mouthfeel. All and all just a great sour. I have four that I am aging and am very excited to see how it processes.

Bottle from whole foods boulder. Pours golden with an inch of white foam. Big red wine notes on the nose. Im getting the red wine from the oak on the tongue as well. Theres a nice amount of tartness as well. Damn good beer!
Funk immediately on the nose. One person described a mustardy tartness, and Id have to agree. Some nice sour notes on a dry finish.

0.375l bottle. Light amber colour. Small white head. Vinager malty aroma with silghty sour taste, oakbarrel and citrus anf sour apples. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2012 9/24/12

Opened right after work.  Mail-order beer.  Nose reminds me of berliner weisse? But additional Brett and a touch of Chardonnay.  Very pleasant.  

Pale gold - looks gorgeous.  Seems super carbonated yet a nice light head.  Interesting how bubbles come up directly from the center of bottom of glass?  this actually does look like the champagne of beers

Taste is wheat, lemon grass and a tiny bit of funk up front...quickly followed by this lovely explosion of Brett and Chardonnay.  Im not even a huge chard fan, but this is the perfect amount of winey oak in the taste.  Very refreshing and in my opinion the perfect amount of tartness.  While carbonation, its not overly bubbly like champers would be - nice mouthfeel.  

One of my favorite sour ales to date

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

17/IX/2012 37.5l bottle @ home - BB: n/a - batch 006 (2012-1052) Thanks to Cory for the bottle!
Clear blond beer, big aery white head, unstable, bit adhesive. Aroma: why yes, definitely a true geuze aroma. Bit dusty, citrus, lemon peel, little fruity, bretta notes, forest fruits. MF: soft carbon, light to medium body. Taste: citric start, lemony, lemon juice, softer bretta taste, very "mellow" tartness, bit spicy. Aftertaste: lemony, hint of white wine, some vinegar, little bitter, dry sour ending.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2012 375 ml bottle. Thanks tiong.
Pours a hazy orange golden colour with a lacy head. Aroma of tart citrus, vanilla, oak and kiwi. Quite extraordinary. Complex flavour of sour berries, citrus, vanilla, white wine, wood, apricot, yeast and green apples. Some honey-like sweetness as well. Medium bodied, soft carbonation and smooth mouthfeel. Finishes fruity with smooth vanilla and some oakiness. Extremely enjoyable and complex. Some wont probably like this, but this was quite a treat at least for me. 8-4-9-4-16 4.1
Draught @ the brewpub, Santa Rosa. Rated on 20.10.2012.
Pours a clear bright golden colour with a small white head. Aroma is very intense with mandarin orange, English toffee and lemon zest. Flavour is really strong in tartness with lemon zest, grapefruit, vanilla, dry wood, cranberries and green apples. Full bodied, dry mouthfeel and a dry, very vinous finish. Very enjoyable and even better as draught. 9-4-9-4-16 4.2

375ml bottle from a trade, thanks stawn!
Batch 006 - Pours musty yellow with a foamy white head. Aroma of tart fruity notes, some bretta and hints of oak, vanilla, wood. Taste has a lot of notes from barrels, with smooth vanilla and oaky notes, some tart fruits, apples and hints of sourness. Finish is smooth with some slightly tart fruits, apples and vanilla oaky notes. Nice, quite untypical and complex but perhaps slightly unbalanced, as the barrel notes come through a bit too much. Still extremely tasty, though.

375ml Bottle from batch 003 
Pours out with just a hint of hazy on a golden background with a fluffy white head that persists forever with massive stickage. The aroma is quite vinous with a sour funky edge. Grapes, lemons, cherries, plums, oranges, tartness, sweaty horses its all in there and it smells great. The first sip pierces my tongue with lactic but smooths out quite quickly. Grapes, candy sugar, brown sugar come up front and provide a great balance against the lemons sour cherries and apricots that come in next. A bit of lactic and funk find its way in there towards the finish but smooth out with a fruity sweetness. Medium body with a spirited level of carbonation and a sweet tart mouthfeel. This is a beautiful beer! Wonderfully complex and incredibly drinkable. Ive had this in the cellar a few years and have lost track of where I got it, if you sent it to me thank you so much.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2013 Stinky cheese butt on the nose... Good, right?  There is a  good bit of mustardy tartness in there, followed up by some subtle cherry notes.  Really effervescent and tastes like a sour tongue depresser.  Overall pretty damn good!

Clean, thin, sour Bret on the nose. Clear blonde pour with a thin white head. Perfectly tart flavor, just enough to raise an eyebrow, without being offensively sour. Crisp light mouthfeel. A very accessible sour beer.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2013 (2010: batch 05X1F): Gracieuseté de pushkinwow. Le premier regard est marquant, une robe blonde 24k, étincelante se tient debout sans broncher. Larôme est celle dun vin blanc frais et dune touche florale. Cest une fois la première gorgée que je saisi pourquoi laura autours de cette série de bières sauvages. Très juteux en début de bouche avec la pomme, poire, raisin vert. Ça devient ensuite rapidement surette alors que les tannins et le bouquet floral étouffent subtilement le contraste. Plus on la boit, plus les saveurs sont balancés. Vraiment superbe.

bottle from Marina Market.  Golden color with a thin white head.  Lots of carbonation.  Very yeasty, bread smell.  Taste is very dry and tart,  Sour apples are mostly what I taste.  There is a similar yeast taste to most saisons.  This is a very good beer.

Golden pour, frothy head.  Mild wine-like aroma.  Chardonnay flavors are apparent with mild oak notes.  Not a lot of bret in this one.  Dry in the mouthfeel.  Good, but not as sour as I was expecting.

Near perfection when aged for about 2 years. Almost no funk on the nose but gorgeous sour flavors come through with every sip. White wine and citrus mouthfeel and back of tongue tastes.  Love this beer. Could sip for hours.
UPDATED: JUL 21, 2012 Bottle. Thanks to adnielsen for the bottle. Aromas of sour pears, apple, and vinegar. White wine, sour apples flavor.
Tangy on the tongue, small body, lightly carbed. Hides the alcohol very easily. Color is a beautiful golden, a bit hazy but that might come from me pouring in nearly the entire body.

bottle [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ taproom. clear golden with very little head. sour aroma of sour fruit. sour taste. very lambic-like, but a bit smoother

375 ml @ Baileys Taproom, Portland.
Pours pale clear golden color with no head. Aroma of sour fruits, grapes, grass, white wine notes and wood. Flavour of sour fruits, grapes, wood, apples, yeast notes and some wine elements. Sour and very dry palate.
3365

37,5 cl bottle at Baileys Taproom, Portland
Aroma is sour with earthy notes and apples - feels like a lambic. Flavour is sour and tart with earthy notes and floury apples. Also some white wine notes. Good!
140712. Bottle at the Baileys Taproom, Portland. Pours clear golden with a small minimal head. Aroma sour fruit, citrus. Sour very Lambic style taste. Not Bad.

Cant believe Ive never rated this.  All from memory, this is a chardonnay-forward blonde sour, prickly, fruity.  Always lots of passion fruit and tropical fruit on the nose and mouth.  Prickly, light bittering hops through the finish.  Superb at about two years, disjointed when young and dusty and acetic at above three years.  Belies the notion that all beer is preferable when fresh, even in this style.  Right now batch 4 is money.  

"I dont believe this.  You bitch.  You came over here just to sleep.  I dont care, Im opening it.  And youre drinking it." [bottle hisses] "Thats a marked improvement." "Seriously?" "No, I have no idea."

A: Pours a gorgeous orange-tinged straw yellow, with a white frothy head and sticky lacing.

S: barn, funk, straw, wood

T: A very balanced and pleasant sour. Incredibly complex, flavors weave together in harmony. This is a delicious treat.

M: warming alcohol, though you can barely detect it. This brew makes ya pucker!

D: A unique beer with that distinctive Russian River taste I thoroughly enjoy. Temptation goes down effortlessly. This is a beer to stock and always have in the cellar.

Comparing my first bottle, Batch 05X1F, against having it many times on draft. Golden pour with a nice light foamy head. Big chardonnay flavors with a perfect juicy backbone. Crisp and full. Fresh drafts are tremendous, and surprisingly a bit better than the red wine version "Supplication" but the bottle smoothes out some rough elements while still leaving a good sour and hoppy bite. Certainly the oaky wine notes dominate but the net effect is better than a wine would deliver. This is just a tremendous beer, both draft and bottle, and needs to be savored. I suspect older bottles will have a smoother syrupy perfection, but what is there right now is simply fantastic!

Pours dark yellow even light orange with a good size white head. Nose is white grapes, funky barnyard aromas, wood and some light spice. Taste is tart for the most part but sweet makes an appearance on the front while bitter joins in at the end. Mouthfeel is crisp and clean but also soft as it warms. Light to medium body and has an exceptionally long finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

@ Avery Sourfest 2012.  Clear gold with a thin white bubbly head. Aroma is plenty funky with notes of dust and hay, with some pale grain maltiness. Taste is pretty good with medium sourness and pale grain sweetness, coupled with some herbal bitterness and some citrus/melon tones. It all comes together pretty nicely.

At FWIBF.  Pours a golden yellow with a white head.  Honey, Brett, Citrus, on the aroma.  The taste Sour with a little sweetness and citrus notes.  Well balanced, great mouthfeel.  Thanks RR for bringing this special bottle the the Fest.

Pour was a deep yellow with dark hues. Head was crisp and quick leaving behind nothing but ale. Lots of sour grapes and apples. Light malty funk. Hints of vinegar. This was quite sour, lots of grape and lemon with hints of apple. The oak was light but carried through out. The funk was well overpowered by the sourness. Lots of carbonation, very tingly. A bit dry in the finish. This was different than the bottle. More amplified and fruit flavored. Granted, could be that they were different batches. Either way, delicious and I bought a bottle to go, so yeah... Drinkable! Reviewed on: 08-16-2010

Batch 006. Pours out to a deep orange/golden yellow with a finger wide white head. Aroma is of bret, barnyard funk, golden raisins, oak, and some light biscuit accents. Flavor is very well balanced - tart apples, acidic oak chips, and grape vines. Not overly sour and good, light carbonation.

Pours a golden 1 finger head into my ccb snifter, a lot of carbonation is present. Aroma of white wine, oak and green apples. Tastes follows the nose, a mix between apple cider, oak and white wine. Very smooth and drinkable. Very tasty, complex yet easy to drink and refreshing.

From a 2011 bottle, aged 6 months. It pours a clear gold color with a pillowy white head and lacing along with a lot of carbonation. The aroma has the brett funkiness, some citrus and a definite Chardonnay profile. The flavor is sour but balanced, with a sweet background and citrus and banana notes. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2012 Poured a rich, almost glistening gold. This beer looks great and practically sparkles in the light. Smells of honey, brett funk, hay, lemongrass, and spice. Taste is much the same, sweet honey, funk, lemongrass, and sourness. It is not too sour, though, much more refined. I love hit-you-in-the-face sours, yet there is something to be said about the balance in this beer. Very elegant and easy drinking, one of RRs best sours.

Pours rich gold with sparse head.  Aroma is very sour oak and brett, chardonnay wine barrel, lemon peel acidity.  Taste is lemon peel, buttery chard barrel, a slight funk and a bright acidity to round it all out.  Body is medium, silky and froth with a tart dry finish.  Overall, this is really something special!
Sampled at Slutfest 3.  Appropriate. thanks N8H. Nice light farmhouse horse blanket funk.  Sweettarts on the flavor. Pretty good and dry on the flavor.  Nice.

Bomb.com. Fizzy sour. Starts off mildly sour but finishes almost buttery like a chordonnay. 

Alan brought a bottle. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thanks to Phredrik for sharing this bottle.. Pours hazy orange with a white head. Aroma is peachy, stableish, hay, funk, some exotic fruits, alot of brett, woody, lemon peel and a nice tartness in general.. Taste is brett, exotic fruits, vinegar, somehow plant juice, acid, weak sulfur, funky, nice tartness and barnyardy .. Once again a nice sour tapped from the russian river ..

Thanks Shawn! Poured into a Duvel Tulip at Cellar Temp. Batch 05x3.

A - Poured a very tiny head that went away quickly. SRM 2 on the scale. Creamy solid white. Lemongrass wheat color, light golden color. Very beautiful. Very light haze.

S - Very tart and sour. Dry champagne scent. Funky and elegant. Earthiness and smell of melons and banana.

T - HUGE explosion of tart. Incredible bitterness. There isnt a huge flavor assigned from a very belgian yeast and old geuze taste. Its hard to pinpoint the flavor. Very very balanced.

M - Dry, 60/40 carbonation on a mouth swish. Tasty as all hell. I love it. Light bodied. An entire bottle alone might be too sour.

O - Wow. A+

Oak, tart grapes, dryness, grass and funky earth.  Medium carbonation is preferred here. Often times sours are flat and this really brings a lightness to the mouth that makes this incredibly drinkable.  Slight minty note from the brett.

Bottle sample at the 3rd Israeli Sour Tasting. Thanks Noam. Batch 006. Clear blond, slim white film of foam. Condensed pungent aroma, tastes a little bitter, but sour-dominated. Light body, oily, light carbonation. Not a sour fun, but this was alright.

Bottle. Pours a clear golden with an off-white head. Aroma is sour and dry, with notes of brett, and sweet candy-like notes behind the sourness. Flavour is sour, dry and sweetish with notes of brett. Finish is a strange dry bitterness; like orange peels, but without the orange- Overall good, but could do with more nuances in the flavour. 30.03.12.

Golden appearance with a thin white head. The nose is powerful and shows plenty of lemon verbena and other vegetal notes with woody accent. Tart, crisp palate with Brett, citrus and even some melon flavors. Endless finish.
Pours a nice golden color with no head at all. Nice grape and sour funk on the nose. Taste is chardonay, white grape and sourness. Beer is nice and dry and easy to drink, another great RR beer.

Bottle at tasting, batch 004x4 traded to me by mashmaster. Pours hazy yellow with a small white head. The aroma resembles white wine quite much. Oak, sweet grapes, peach, tangerine, mango, a good deal of brettanomyces, barnyard. Very fruity and nicely funky, bright and fresh. The taste also has the lot of bright fruit - pineapple, tangerine, citrus, a very well balanced barrel quality, nice brettanomyces and a bit of grainy malt presence. Decently tart on the palate with a slight astringency in the finish. Masterful and hugely enjoyable!

Pours a nice hazy gold with a small white head. The aroma is funky and earthy with hints of chardonnay. The taste is sour, but not too sour.  The palate has lively carbonation and thin body with a very crisp and refreshing finish.  Overall very good beer, the chardonnay barrels add depth to the overall flavor  and give it the extra complexity to make this a great beer.

Pours a clean crisp yellow/orange with a touch of white head. The wine barrel aging is very nice on this beer. This beer is full of sour wild funk and farmy goodness. Very sour and yet very drinkable.

Bottle of batch 004X1. Pours hazy, dark gold with thin, fizzy white head; short retention and spare lacing. Aroma is sour fruit, white grapes/wine, floral notes, straw malt, pepper, and lemon. Flavor is white wine with floral and citrus notes; dry, sour finish. Light body, medium carbonation, and low warmth.

Batch 3

Very nice yellor blonde sour with a perfect amount of carbonation for the style. 

Smells like oak and funk, Just what I expected out of this beer. I have been waiting a long time to try this. Tastes is wonderful sour and dry I get the chardonnay barrel and the brett funk. Really clean and crisp. Definitely a treat

A - pours clear apple juice straw yellow with almost no white head. S - nice aromas of Brett's, funk, apples, white grapes, sour notes. M - nice medium  bodied lightly sour funky beer. Lighter than I remember with a weaker palate. End is a bit abrupt, with only subtle sour lingering. T - funky barnyard aromas  , bretts, on the nose. Sour, white wine, grapes on the palate. Lingering sour and grapes. O - very good beer, great aroma, less spectacular tastes. Not as strong of a showing as I remember. 8

Pours crystal clear golden with a lot of carbonation streaming from the bottom of the glass and a large, fluffy, bright white head. Smells like white wine, light fruits, subtle oak notes, and some Bret funk. Taste is initially sour and then moves to some funkiness at the back end. Full-bodied with a slightly prickly texture and a little less than expected mouth-carbonation, Russian River Temptation finishes with both sour and funk.

Tap at RR. It pours clear golden yellow, with a decent white head. The nose is salt, sawdust, vinegar, playdough and tart grapefruit. The taste is sour white grape, grapefruit, vinous, lemon, lime pith, wood, hay and vinegar, with a tart finish. Well hidden alcohol and great balance. Medium body and low/soft carbonation. Not overly complex, but a tasty sour ale nonetheless.

Been waiting to find this one for a while. Aroma is old wood, sour apple, and a bit of leather. This truly does smell like a Chardonnay, with a little extra funk. It has a straw color with a foamy fizzy white head. The flavor is quite tart at first with a lemony flavor followed by a musty funk and yeasty note. The finish is a lasting sour on my tongue that is crisp and dry. I like that this flavor is produced with added fruit, allowing you to really get to the heart of the funky character. This is great.

12 oz draft @ TJs 8. Pours a hazy light gold with a perfect small white head. Nose is dusty, funky wood, some lemon and a bit of malt in there too. Skinless grapes and dry wood hit the palate hard accompanied by recognizable RR brett, some lactic sourness, light citrus, and white vinegar. One of my favorite RR sours for sure, wish it was available more often.

From notes.  First reviewed2/12/2011.  Poured from a 375 mL bottle into a tulip. Batch 05X1E.

With a slow pour to keep the yeast sediment out, Temptation pours a golden yellow color, slightly hazy with a modest white head. The head retains nicely and leaves a thick sheet of lace all the way down the glass.

Some barnyard funk, tons of oak, and great tart golden fruits open up the aroma. Tart apples, pear, and white grape are all present. A bit of grassy hops close out the nose.

The sour flavors kick in right away. Sour green apple is the first flavor on the tongue, along with white grape. A huge acidic oaky flavor, from the Chardonnay barrels, complements the grape well. The Bretty funk and sour character builds and takes control after a brief grassy hop flavor toward the end of the sip. The finish is very sour, and the sour flavor lingers.

This definitely causes me to salivate profusely and my cheeks to pucker. Mostly crisp with a subdued smooth creaminess contained in the medium carbonation. The body feels a bit above medium. The oak definitely makes its presence known, and it is somewhat dry and quite acidic.

This is one of my first ventures into the realm of the true sours, and I enjoyed the trip. The nose and flavor are complex and interesting, and this may lead to a new obsession. The candidly sour flavor will not let you down this quickly, but it will be a fun glass.

Bottle. White head on a slightly hazy bright gold. Oaky sour and lactic acid aromas. Woody and not as overpowering on the sour front with sour grapes and lactic notes. Lighter body and tart with soft carbonation.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Yeasty with a vinous nose this beer is a unique joy to drink. Its deep gold/ orange colour belies the different nuances that exist within its body. The Bret influence is there and so is the wine side but all in all what makes this so nice is the fact that drinkability is key to its makeup.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2012 375 ml bottle courtesy of tkrjukoff. Shared at epic tasting on February 11. Pours clear golden with a small creamy white head that leaves no trace while quickly dissipating. Smell is sour and funky with lemon juice, orange zest, some sweet fruits and dusty farmyard. Taste is sour with grapes, lemon juice, orange peal, sweet fruits, hay, leather and wood. Mouthfeel is sour, slightly watery and very balanced. Finish is tart with citrus fruits and farmyard hints.Re-rate: Batch 003 courtesy of Marsiblursi. Bright orange, no head. Very nice and sour gooseberry / unripe berry / barnyard aroma. Nice sour and slightly sweet taste with green grapes, wood, peaches, currants, gooseberries and hints of oxidation. Very nice. Feel my first rating of this was quite unfair.
UPDATED: OCT 6, 2013 Another good sour from RR. not as good as consecration or supplication but up there!

Bottle. The pour was a murky medium yellow with an average sized (1-2 finger) white frothy head that reduced to just a thin foamy film that hung to the sides of the glass thus producing some excellent sheeting of lace.

The aroma was harsh of a grain malt and a funky moldy yeast (Brett) with notes of peach, pears, lemon and a winey oak scent.

The taste was slightly sweet and tart with a note of peach in the beginning then quickly got extremely sour with a big dose of citrus and a hint of wine and wood at the end. The flavor stuck around for a good long while after the swallow with a nice sour citrusy taste left to lie on the taste buds.

Mouthfeel was just a tad under medium in body with a nice dry creamy texture and an extremely lively carbonation.

Overall a seriously sour brew with great notes of citrus, wine and oak. Which all together make this a very delectable tasting beer.

Pours clear golden with a small bubbly off ehite head leaving smsll laces. Aroma is fruity, sour, sweet, honeyish. Flavor is sour, tart, vinous, fruity, dry yet has some sweetness, crisp, berry, bitter and malty. Finishes sour fruity tart.

Bottle at "Alex surölsprovning 2012". Golden, almost no head. Fruity aroma, sourish, grapefruit, malty, fruity, sour, yeasty notes. Fruity yeasty flavor,, sourish, grapefruit, woody, some figs. Long. Fruity sourish finish, grapefruit and citrus.
Taste like drinking some tequilla. Has a slight sour taste. No bitterness. Its a good sour.
Pours golden with frothy white head. Beautiful peach and pear notes throughout, with oak and vanilla really putting it over the top. Unreal
pours very light yellow with a small white fizz. Aroma is sweet and sour. Flavor is kinda light finishes off more sour than it starts. Very good sour.
Bottled 375ml. Courtesy of magdalar. Complex, tart with a lot of brett and vanilla. Mindblowingly delicious. Huge thanks magdalar!

Clear pale yellow with a smaller white head nice lacing ... Lemony funky tart lightly sour nice aroma lots of oak wood vanilla... Lighter than Expected, nice flavor fairly lively some notes of peach/mango vanilla wood oak... Lots of flavor, dryer finish... Nice beer, not my favorite RR tho

Pours a clear pale yellow/gold with a medium white head...lively.  aroma is light and refreshing mango and peach with nice bretty sour notes.  Flavor is more soury and oaky...dry white wine like notes.  Mouthfeel is a bit watery up front...very light...and the finish is dry and oaky/winey.
375 ml. bottle.  Batch 05 X 1E.  Pours light gold with a thin white head.  Aroma of tart citrus and grapes.  Taste is dry wine, malt, apple, and grapes.  Nice balance of sour and sweet.

Poured a slightly cloudy yellow to tan color, bubbly with a so-so head but very nice lacing.

Smells as funky as any beer Ive had. Tart lemon and white cake icing are the two things that first come to mind. Really funky with plenty of sawdust and freshly sawed wood (thats a good thing, I like the smell of sawed wood although I realize its a strange descriptor).

Taste... WOW. No shortage of that. Powerfully sour lemons almost like someone was making beer lemonade and forgot the sugar. Somewhat like a tart and dry white wine. Some crab apple notes. Woody like sawdust, like being in a large wood shop. Some metallic notes.

Strongly carbonated and medium bodied. Fairly dry. Leaves a lingering tart aftertaste.

Bottle.  Hazy golden beer with a medium lasting white head.  Sour, sweet fruity aroma, some citrus and wood.  Taste is sweet, very nicely sour, vinous, dry finish.  Medium bodied, well carbonated.  Great stuff.
Pours golden with fizzy white head.  Nose is smelly sour lemons and flowers.  Tart lemon and bread.  Good.  Kind of mellow.

Bottle. Pours a clear golden with white head. Smells of Chardonnay, farmyard, light fruits. Tastes refreshing, with a medium sour grape juice feel and flavor. Creamy texture, but very acidic. Its good, but meh.

12.7oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours deep but transparent golden with an off-white head.  Aroma of sweet tarts and sourness, some light white wine and light oak, light fruits, and spiciness.  Flavor the same, pretty sour.  Bubbly texture.  A really good sour.

750ml corked and caged bottle. Batch 4x2. Served in a Blvd. tulip. Poured a clear, pale gold with a couple of fingers of big bubbled white head. Plenty of carbonation. Bottle conditioned. Lots of brett in the aroma, also some barrel. Light bodied, dry and effervescent. Nice and tart. Amazingly long finish with some oak. Very drinkable. Fantastic beer.

This one is subtle and not overly tart.  Pours a blonde color with white head.  Aroma is funky apple/lemon with other light fruity elements.  Taste is light vinegar with subtle oak and chardonay notes and strong tart apple. Pretty nice
Great tart apply aroma. Taste is sharp and fresh. Like a sassy broad. Some lactic Flavors.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2012 NEED TO RERATE THIS NOW THAT I LIKE SOUR ALES.I dont get it. I tolerate it better than the first time. But, really now....why? No, seriously, why? There are so many other ways you could get this same taste for so much less money. Lick a horse, for example. Squeeze lemon juice into an old sneaker, soak overnight, squeeze, drink...enjoy. Chew a well-used jock strap. The aroma is simply off putting to normal people. To curious beer lovers, it is, at best, an odd thing, like watching kangaroos mate, or something. Ill leave it to those with more sophisticated palates to describe the lovely intricacies of this....beer?.....as Im sure my description would be pure blasphemy of this bacteria-ladden work of fart...I mean art.

Bottle shared with Anker. Pours bit hazy yellow with a medium white head. The aroma is citrus, grape fruit, acid, oak, wood and some wine notes. Nice bretty flavour with notes of grapes, citrus, wet wood and oak. Nice complexity and very authentic.

The taste is wonderful. I was a bit surprised at the lack of bite due to sour. From the sour beers I have had before, there has been a bite to the sour. I personally felt there was not a lot to the palate in the back. There was a lot of taste to the palate up front and a tinge of champagne mouth fill. The color is cloudy, yet transparent. I imagine I will always love to have this beer.

Batch 4 750 mL bottle. Pours clear golden honey with a nice off white head. The aroma is sweet with subtle sour notes blended so well together with light wine notes from the chardonnay barrels. The flavor is similar starting with a blend of pure sweet and sour notes and light grape flavors that have a smooth but dry ending.

Bottle courtesy of thome50.  Hazy and brilliant gold.  Frothy white top with active, even carbonation.  Pinot, lemon citrus, tang, soft spice, mild funk.  Lemon, a little granny smith, pinot, vanilla/wood in the finish.  Mild dryness.  Residual lemon citrus and some bitterness.  Again, well done and refreshing.  They have a way...

Tap @ Parkway. Clear gold pour with a persistent, short white head leaving heavy lace. Fruity, sour nose with a hint of Brett. Medium-light body and carbonation, with a very pleasant tartness. Apple, white grape, pear, Brett funk and some lemon. Finish is fairly short and tart, with a late hint of butterscotch. There is a bit more of Lactobacillus than Brettanomyces in the sourness, but the balance is incredibly right. Its amazing to me that they can judge the amount of refermentation and bottle/keg aging that will occur with this mix. A lovely drop that I would go well out of my way for.

This beer pour beautiful golden and clear with no head but some bubbly carbonation. Nose is oakes wines, light Brett funk and some evident lactic qualities blended in. Flavor is some sweet malts, then fades to dry wine and with inside lots of lactic flavors and Light Brett. This is more on the lactic side than Brett character. Mild and good for a beginner.

(Batch 006)  This starts with an amazing aroma, with hints of sour apples, brett funk, and a touch of oak.  Pours a clear gold color, with a large fluffy white head.  This has a delicious tart flavor, with hints of apple and white wine notes.  Light on the palate, and very easy drinking.  This is an amazingly delicious beer

375ml c&c bottle, batch 6, from woodchopper on BA, thanks Jamie.  pours a mostly clear straw yellow with a very smallish white head.  aroma is light funk, a little bit acidic and grapes.  very mild funky sour flavor with some white wine, grapes and some lemon/citrus on the end.  light body with medium-high carbonation.  very nice.

Pours a very light yellow with a good-sized head that quickly dissipates. Aroma is rather muted--some fruitiness, but not very apparent. Flavor is sour and fruity. Some citrus. Very wine-like. These sour/wild ales are starting to grow on me.
Bottle at Jose Pistola.  Poured in a wine glass... Looks exactly like chilled white wine with light suds along the side. White grape, sweet champagne, and some mellow oak to round it out.    3.85

I poured a 375ml corked and caged bottle into a champagne flute.

Appearance: Champagne or lager-like complexity of bright white gold with massive carbonation bubbles present. Forms a good sized white foamy head which laces and retains very well.

Smell: White grape, straw, sour candy. 

Taste: A lot of people wave a flag on drinkers like me that enjoy overly sweet flavored stouts and other beers because theyre basically just liquid candy. But cant the same be said for sours? Drinking Russian River Temptation is like drinking liquid sour candy like Sour Patch Kids. Its very sour, tart, sweet, refreshing and delicious. I guess these types of beers get a pass because theyre made with "wild" yeast which have to be handled with care. Plus this beer was aged in French Chardonnay oak barrels (although I get no wood character from this beer).

It begins with immediate sourness - sharp and to the point. Theres a subtle sweetness through the middle with a fruity-like taste of white grape. Then it transitions back to its sour edge, turning more towards tartness like an unripe grape or berry. Its an interesting and fun mix of sourness and sweetness with a short, but intense sour aftertaste which lingers for a little while and builds up by the time you finish the bottle.

Mouthfeel: Thin, crisp with extremely fine carbonation tingling. Leaves a sugary aftertaste of sourness and seems to numb the tongue.

Drinkability: For an overtly sour beer, bottle-conditioned and highly effervescent, Russian River temptation is remarkably easy to drink. The flute glass helps concentrate it to the middle of the tongue instead of the entire mouth and no carbonation gets stuck in the throat. It goes down smooth, although there is a dry aftertaste. The 7.5% seems right on the money. On one hand it has the robustness of something stronger; but on the other hand it drinks and feels like an even lighter beer. Nice to see an American sour that is comparable to the Belgians.

Pours a clear gold color with a nice white head and good lacing. Aroma is sour malt and lemon. The taste is amazing, slightly sour, decnt malt, little to no hops. Sessionable. Amazing sour, I wish I could have this every day.

Golden pour with very dry bubbly head. Head dissipates quickly leaving a lot of lacing.

Strong Brett nose very dry.
body is light, carbonated, sour, earthy with a little citrus. 
Mellow dry bitter finish. Very Nice!
38cl, Batch 3, exclusive American brew, thx to Walt!, very complex sour brew, sour/woody and slightly vinous/fruity, very balanced, cloudy, rocky head, very good brew!

12-oz bottle courtesy of James split with James and Streets. Drank from a snifter. Shimmery gold pour with very small white head. Aroma is acidic and light. Taste is sweet and a little cutting with a definite imprint from the Chardonnay barrels giving it a grape-white wine flavor. Palate is light as hell with almost no aftertaste. Almost too wine-like. Not very bold or sour imo.

Nice Wild Ale. The oak isnt apparent until the finish and the carbonation is just a bit more than I prefer. The mouthful is nice and not to thin or viscous. Its almost like a Saison with Brett added. I get some peach and white grapes that Im guessing, comes from the yeast. I think this is an excellent wild ale to introduce people to Brett C. Its too funky and is a good representation of the style. I dont think this is one is too complex but all in all a solid offering from Russian River.

Ported from BA.

My second sour ever. Thanks to my girlfriend for helping me get a bottle.

Appearance:
A very clear yellow color with a single finger of head that dissipated in the time it took me to get to this sentence since clicking review. Carbonation bubbles.

Smell:
Kind of like white grapes. A champagne smell maybe, no hints of alcohol. Semi-sweet.

Taste:
More of that sourish white grape flavor, with hints of orange peel and lemony citrus. Its like a sour candy! Lots of character in this one. Slightly sweet malt flavor, definitely sour instead of bitter. Id call it delicious.

Mouthfeel:
Thicker than I was expecting, and it kind of washes over your mouth and sticks to you. It leaves a bubbly sour film, which slowly slips away, leaving you feel like youve just eaten sour candy.

Drinkability:
Reasonably high. Due to the price and sourness (my tongue starts to hurt after too much sour), I couldnt drink several of them, but on the right night, I can definitely drink one and really enjoy it.
On tap at the brewery.  This was Ks favorite of a sample of all 16 of their taps.  white wine, apple, grape, oak - then funk and sour.  incredible balance.  long tart/sour finish.  8.0
At iron abbey beer dinner. Aroma and taste of banana, with sour/tart-ness. MIKEY likey sour ale.
At iron Abbey beer dinner.  Aroma is strong banana chips.  Taste is sour tart, some fruitiness, banana again.  Not my favorite rr, but good.
Had at Russian river beer dinner hosted by iron abbey on September 21. Vanilla and banana in the nose. Refreshing grapefruit and sour on the finish.

pours hazy straw, lots of carbonation. milky ring of permanent white head. Sour apple, cedar , oak, esters, lemon zest on the nose. White grapes, funk, acidic Brett sourness, tart and dry on the tongue. effervescent, long finish. light and quite enjoyable. Great sour.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2011 Bouteille de 375 ml, batch 05x3. Arômes très citronnés de levures sauvages, touche vineuse et boisée. Robe blonde et très légèrement trouble, effervescence assez active, belle mousse qui disparaît rapidement. En bouche, la bière se montre très citronnée et présente un caractère qui rappelle également les écorces de pamplemousse. On remarque également une belle composante vineuse et boisée. Elle nest peut-être pas aussi complexe que les meilleures gueuzes, mais le caractère orienté vers les fruits et les agrumes est particulièrement agréable et la rend très facile à boire. Finale présentant une acidité lactique et citrique dintensité moyenne. Une autre bière sure de grande classe provenant de Russian River.

375ml corked and caged bottle. Batch 05X1E.

It pours a brilliant yellowish orange with a nice foamy white head that leaves some nice lacing.

The smell is bretty and fruity. It isnt that potent of a smell though. I am getting a faint bit of pineapple and a faint sourness. There is also a bit of malt. Odd that I cant really smell this one, might just be me.

The flavor is nice though. It is not really sour but bretty. the brett shines in this brew, if you like it then you will like this brew. A bit of funk and lemon paired with a nice malt and a hit of oak and wine bill complete this brew.

A very nice one from Russian River.

Draught at Russian River Brewery. 
Honey lemon, funky nose, with vanilla and yogurt; very lactic. Clear gold with nice lace, sparkling. Quite sourwith lemon meringue, yogurt, horse blanket. Clean and tasty, though a bit sweeter than I prefer. Oily, silky palate. Great.

Bought back in November at Belmont Station in Portland. Batch 05. Hazy gold brew with a fizzy white cap that lives on as a healthy rim. Wonderful scrumptious brett with pineapple, sourness, lightly cheezy, lemon, some type of cheap pasta with sauce (I just havent nailed which one down), warm tropical notes,  some sweetness when warmer, touch of oak and some sweat - Overall really wonderful and inviting. Awesome flavour. Perfect level of mellow sourness with a heavy bite that only lasts a short time before fading into mild leather. Tartness, faint vinegar harshness.. very faint and I only found it after really thinking about it. Watery spice, oak, sour lemon, quite drying, vinous... yummy. Amazingly drinkable in large gulps. A wonderful treat for sure.

On tap at Russian River. Pours a light golden color with slight white head, some lacing. Light aroma, really had to sniff deep, smells a little of citrus and strongly like a bottle of Chardonnay. Sour taste with a very blatant Chardonnay flavor, some citrus on the background. Light body with a smooth citrusy finish. Overall a must have sour from Russian River. This and Supplication are easily my two favorites.

Bottle - Batch 002. Poured a hazy golden with a fizzy white head that left some lasting. Farmhouse aroma with some backing of lemon and barrel. Tart flavor of citrus and fruit. Light body, tart, and dry.

375ml bottle poured into snifter. Been dying to try this for a long time. Clean pour with orange hazy color. Aroma has hints of sour lime and lemon juice. Flavor is a little oaky with a tart sour funk to it. Gives the jaw a little tickle but not overly sour. Very tasty and easy drink.

This is a must taste beer!  One of my top four choices from Russian River, the Temptation predominately tastes like a sour.  The aroma is super smooth, but doesnt really reflect the sourness youre about to experience!

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2011 Served on-tap into a mini pint at TJs 7th Anny. Party. Number three of three in my Russian River flight. An amazing party with amazing beers.

A - Pours pale yellow with a spotty white head leaving minimal lacing down the glass. Quite pale but very inviting.

S - Strong sour notes up front with a bit of sweetness. Some lemon, white grape, and a few other earthy notes. The sourness is strong but not overpowering.

T - Tart up front slowly giving way to bright citrus flavors, similar to the nose, finishing with a lingering biternes that fades after a short time. A very nice wild ale, tart but not overpowering. My favorite of the three.

M - Medium body and head with moderate carbonation. Overall dry feel with a good amount of sourness in the finish, not lingering on the pallet for very long.

D - Very high. While it is a bit dry the sourness helps to balance it all out. One of the most enjoyable wilds I have had. I am glad I have a few of these in the cellar.

bottle, from trade with Carny77, I think,  batch 004x5. Good aroma, tart, yeasty, mild funk about it, vanilla, chardonnay barrel shows itself. Clean golden orange color, Good head that faded quicly, minor lace. Tart sour flavor, Medium body, smooth mouthfeel, dry tart finish, Very nice, like the amount of barrel it had, went well with the yeasty funk, got funkier as warmed.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Tasted on 7/26/11 from a 750mL corked and caged bottle obtained in a trade, batch 004x3.  Pours hazy, bright orange with a thick, smooth white head that slowly recedes to spotty lace with a decent collar, leaving some residue lace along the inside of the glass.  The nose is very sour with lemon acidity, slightly lactic and fruity, and also has some light malt and brett funk.  The flavor is very sour and lactic up front with acidic lemon fruitiness, light malt, and brett funk.  The body is medium , and slightly oily with lively carbonation and a long acidic lemon, funky brett and tannic finish.

Thanks John! Must have more of this. I shared this beer with 2 or three other people. Not enough!!! Yeah Im rocking through a sour phase right now, and this beer only adds to the funk nasty tart snowball effect. Great sour. Good fruit. The Chard grapes come out full force but are impeccably balanced. Not a cheap Chardonnay barrel. This was the real deal. Id pay damn good money to have this again.

750ml 2009 bottle. Hazy gold blonde body; thin head. Very intense buggy aroma. Very lively body, spritzy. Sour of course. Nothing groundbreaking, just very very well done. Reminds me of Petrus Aged Pale.

A very enjoyable sour ale. Pours light golden, with small white head. Hazy, lots of lacing. Looks brilliant, if that was all that mattered this beer would be top of the charts. Aroma is a bit weak. Tropical fruits, wheat, yeast. Taste is very rich, sourness second to none, grapes, slightly bitter finish, quite nice. Body is full for the style, with moderate carbonation. Overall, a very enjoyable example of the style.

A very carbonated pour from the bottle, big bubbly off white head, which dissipates quickly. Hazy straw yellow pour.I smell Oak, Tropical fruit, some alcohol and funk as the beer warms up.
Delicious wild ale taste, tart, yeast, and bready, a subtle oak barrel woodiness, a soft spicy hoppiness, the alcohol is well masked, but warming in the palate, and a dry. Palate is medium to thin which makes this very drinkable. The sourness is present in the taste, but is not overpowering. RR knows what its doing.
Golden yellow with a white head. American hops, slight bretty funk, some honey and notes of bread. Clear notes of white wine as well.

batch 4x3, 750ml. cant believe i hadnt rated this. pours a light yellow to fairly saturated ornage color with some sparse and airy white head that leaves some thick lacing at the original pour line. the aroma and flavor and great with some tartness upfront and then light refreshingness in back. yummy. a solid classic, this one does great with a few years on it.

Aroma: bretta, oak, wild
Appearance: deep orange
Taste: medium sourness, oak notes
Palate: medium to full body
Overall: 19/20
Pours a hazy honey yellow with full white head and lacing. Pleasant sour aroma. Sweetness and sour taste. Sour is slightly muted and blends well with subtle oak taste. Well rounded and drinkable.

Frischer, leicht säuerlicher Antrunk, etwas hopfig. Durch den hohen CO2 Gehalt prickelt das Bier auch noch im Mittelteil auf der Zunge. Die Aromen ändern sich hier nicht, insgesamt wird es aber stärker. Im Abgang kommt eine leichte Hopfigkeit hinzu, die Säuerlichkeit ist weiter im Vergleich schwach ausgeprägt. Auf Dauer etwas eintönig. 	 
Test vom 14.8.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: -,9,9,8,12,9 - 9,00
On the nose it has a geuze like aroma. The taste is of corked Chardonnay that has been watered down but with a very subtle geuze like quality coming through.
another great sour from russian river, plenty of sourness from this one, out of a bottle and at gabf last year

Batch 1 and 4 at Trias fermentation school. Great beer. Light yellow, almost red color. Decent head. Good nose of some barnyard funk, sour tartness.  Taste is the same, funky sourness, more of tart taste. Medium body, close to the lighter side. Oveall a unique sour beer.

375ml bottle, batch 05X2E.  Pours a light yellow-amber color with a white head.  Aroma is sour, fruity, apples.  Light on the palate with soft carbonation.  Flavor is sour, oak, funk, grapes, wine.  Truly somewhere between beer and wine. Excellent.
13th June 2009Hazy amber gold beer. Dry palate. Sour but with the edges taken off by some dry woodiness. The sourness is citric and with a touch of peach. Not my favourite style but this is ok.

375mL bottle from Downtown Joes in Napa, CA poured into a tulip glass. Pours a medium/dark golden color with very little head, medium carbonation. Can smell the sourness right away, slight citrus aromas. Very little lacing around the edge of the glass. Not a very "drinkable" beer for me, sour ales are not my favorite. Very well done beer though.

Bottle at home kindky shared by oj83! Was interested to try this highly rated sour! Unfortunately I didnt think is was as good as its reputation! Tasted alongside some top Belgian geuze this appeared weak in taste, palate and aroma! Nice beer and similar to a geuze but its just not quite up there!

Bottle thanks once again to Owen. Pours a brillaint very light straw with smallish white head. Aromas for me are dominated by coconut, light vinegary sourness and a touch of wood. Really good stuff. Light sourness dominates the flavours. Very dry finish. Lively mouthfeel. Good stuff.
From corked bottle. The Chardonnay barrels aged the beer well. Mild sourness with mellow complexity.
Batch 1 from TheBeerGod @ the Birch tasting.  Wood, fruit and funk on the nose.  Mellow sour enhanced by wood.  Overall amazing.

12.68oz corked and caged bottle, Batch 05X2E, purchased from City Beer and shared with Photog.  Pours orange and gold, light-colored, with wispy clouds of very, very fine particles in suspension.  The head is thin, light white, and short-lived.  The aromas are sour cherry and mild acetic acid, oak, some sugary strawberry and raspberry with mild peach, and Chardonnay.  The flavor is sour grape, cherry, and tart and buttery oak.  Mild, woody bitterness creeps in, with cherry stones evident.  White wine and Chardonnay are present in the finish, with mild alcohol.  This is complex and tart, but not puckering.  Spritzy and effervescent, medium-bodied, and nearly creamy, while refreshing and dry.  Absolutely great; another delicious Russian River offering.  [715]

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2012 First ratingBottle thanks to Reza! Sampled on May 24, 2011Clear pale honey yellow color, small white head. Acidic to sour scent, some cheese and oak. Moussy mouthfeel, acidic aftertaste. Acidic to sour taste, some apples and wood. Very low bitterness. Somewhat metallic and unripe red berries character.6/3/7/3/12=3.1RerateBottled 375 mlat the epic sour beer tasting at _angst_ place, on February 11, 2012Brought by tkrjukoff, thanks!Marked 7.5% ABVHazy yellow to golden color, white head. Acidic, sour, oak scent. Light, acidic, sour, oak taste. Sour aftertaste. Medium low mouthfeel, very low bitterness.8/3/7/3/14=3.5

375ml bottle batch 05 1F. Pours a hazy yellow with with an off white head like a bubbly apple juice. Smells very like a dry chardonnay, wood, and light brett. Taste is a little sweet and partly tart, finish is extremely dry but bit of a floral/hoppy bite. I get what RR is going for here and this is something that I would love on a hot summer day; however I would pick other RR sours over this most of the time.

From a bottle at Café 3 små rum, Göteborg, Sweden. Pale golden, small white head. Wonderful fruity and slightly funky aroma with green apples, pineapples, butter and wood. Medium bodied and smooth. Dry with a gentle acidity. Simply wonderful.

Thanks Wavers1 for 300th rating. Pour slight hazy yellow head. Aroma tannin, acidic, sour, oak. Taste oak, white wine, acidic, sour. MF medium body fizzy carb. Overall very good beer awesome tasty stuff.

This was one good experience.  Golden hazy color with a white head.  Smell of strong chardonnay, woody, smells tart.  No hop detected.  Dry, very dry.  Taste is sweet and very tart.  Tastes like a dry chardonnay with a woody after taste.  C02 is lively.  Fruit forward.  lots going on.
Pours a hazy yellow golden color with a creamy white head. Notes of lemons, burlap, toasted oak, and wild yeast. Moderate mouthfeel with a sour lasting finish. Nice.
This is what a sour should be!  Some spice, an odd yeast bitterness.  Some chardonnay.  Big sourness.  Nice wood flavors.  Complex fruit.  Delicious.

Bottle. Pours hazy orange yellow with a medium bright white head. Aroma is citrus fruits, yeast, grass, and pineapple. Flavor is lemon, white grapes, pineapple, under-ripe peaches. Medium fizzy mouthfeel.

Bottle courtesy of Pailhead. Pours a hazy gold with a thin lingering white head. Aroma is spicy with notes of candied fruit, and brett. Body is light, and crisp. Flavor is sharply sour, with a nice brett finish.

Pours straw yellow, mostly opaque.  Very inviting white head that has a little staying power.  smells of wine, citrus, hops and lemon especially.  Very tart, and sour (as a sour ale would imply).  tart keeps popping to mind, very wine like as well.  Effervescent, and tasty.  Hits hard on the sour, but good.

Bottle, batch 05x2E.  Aroma is quite vinous, lots of tart fruits, lemon, grapes.  Pours a very clear straw color, white head with good retention and lots of lacing.  A refreshing burst of mildly sour fruit to start with; lemon and grapes are most noticeable, faint grain character, lots of wine flavors.  Faint initial sweetness fades to a very dry finish.  Light body and high carbonation; very effervescent.  A delicious beer, this really shows a great deal of wine character, exceptionally well done.
Murky golden pour. Sour cherrie aroma, wine. Oak. White wine, grape. Just an excellent brew.
Bottle. Bright golden amber with a soft thin white head. Strong sour scent. Georgeous sour fruit flavour. Feels like it is drawing the citrus out of your tongue rather than the other way around.

Batch 4. Poured from a bottle into a becher glass. Beer is yellow (eventually the sediment got released and ended up clouding the beer but it started out pretty clear). Thick white head of medium bubbles held up shortly by moderate carbonation of medium to large bubbles that rose through the beer quickly. Head leaves a lot of lacing on the glass as the beer is drank.

Beer has a good sour aroma followed by a slight funk. Sour aroma seems citric rather than acetic or lactic.

Whoa, this is a sour. Puckering citric sour flavors. Once the shock wore off, its amazing. Beer is really smooth. Drinkability high, mouthfeel great. Crisp finish, no aftertaste, there is a hint of oak in the back after drinking for a while. This is a great beer.

Serving type: bottle

UPDATED: APR 10, 2011 The beer pours a lightly carbonated, cloudy straw gold color. The head is about 1 finer high, decent retention, weak lacing just kind of runny. 

The aroma right off the bottle is sour funk horse blanket, but once the intial nose is gone it is a very light sensation thats tough to pick up anything on. There is a light grape smell, light notes of flowers, hops. 

The taste is amazing. It starts off light and sweet but then right away you get a stront tart bite and a hard sour finish.

Mouthfeel is surprinsgly strong with a great drinakability

Bottle from a trade with wavers1. Pours slightly cloudy pale yellow color with white head. Slightly musty aroma with brett, oak, wine and some floral scents. Tart flavor with some oak ane wine aith a good dose of brett funkiness. Light and crisp mouthfeel. Lots of effevescence. An excellent brew. Thanks Baker.

Effervescent golden yellow, white foam.  Aroma is a peach skin mustiness, sweaty sock, light tartness, lemon.  Taste is dry, more brett character, floral, musty, some white wine, apple, green grapes.  Nice.  High carbonation lends to an almost creamy body.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2012 A - Pours a slightly hazy golden-orange color with a thin finger of frothy white head. The head fades down at a normal pace leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is full of white grape and other light fruits with some sourness and funk. There is also some oak as well as a bit of vanilla and some Brett.

T - Starts off with some sour white grape and other light fruits with some Brett funk and some tartness. Through the middle, the oak and vanilla come through with some more tartness and hay and other barnyard flavors. The finish is a mix of sour grape and chardonnay with some oak, Brett, funk, and tartness.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a sour and dry finish.

D - Very drinkable. Really nicely balanced sour. The barrel character comes through really nicely alongside all of the sour and funky flavors.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2012 Bottle thanks to sideshowe in a trade.  Batch 5, 375 ml bottle.  Pour is ever so slightly hazy straw-like yellow with a small white head.  Loads of tiny bubbles rising up to the surface on this one.  Aroma is earthy with fresh cut grass, some lemon, menthol maybe, and slightly herbaceous.  Taste starts with some acidity on the tip of the tongue which then transitions some earthiness towards the mid palate.  Maintains a hint of sourness throughout.  Finish is reminiscent of buttered popcorn.  Phenomenal!  Thanks ton Eric!

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2011 375ml bottle. Batch 5.  Pours a beautiful yellow blond with a very small head the quickly diminished.  Funky aroma of bretty funk, lemongrass, fresh cut grass, and uncharred wood.  There is a lot going on in this beer that comes in waves.  Starts fast with a high level of acidity reminicent to sucking on a lemon, which leads into this yeasty, funky, earthy, middle which flows so decadently into a long finish that tastes like hot buttered popcorn.  Sounds like a horrible way to describe it, but thats what it tastes like! Makes perfect sense that this was aged in chardonnay barrels, hence the butteriness in the finish.  A fantastic sour.  Thanks mattyb83!

Re-rate from 6/8/11:
Visited batch 3 and 4.  Time does this beer well.  Both batches rounded out well over time with more mellow acidity.  Softer, well rounded, and not nearly any of the chardonnay "hot buttered popcorn". Awesome.

Poured from a 375ml bottle.  Pours golden yellow, clear with white head.  Aroma is chardonnay wine and some bret.  Taste is dry champagne, buttery chardonnay and some funk.  

I am not a big sour fan, but this was pretty drinkable.  It had the unfortunate timing to follow after Churchills Finest, which was a big, sweet, thick stout.

Bottle. Poured a hazy golden color with a massive white head. The nose consists of brett, funk, sour apple, oak and a citrus lemon zest. The taste is much of the same with the addition of white grapes and a great chardonnay profile. This is a beer I could easily drink all day and never tire of.

Pours a clear golden orange. Thin white head that leaves a thin ring. Moderate aroma of Brett funk. Flavor is earthy funkiness followed by tart fruitiness. Clean, fizzy mouthfeel  Slightly dry, acidic finish.

Batch 4.

slightly hazy - bubbly white head sticking to the side of the glass in a 1/4" thickness that stays around.

smells lactic with oak and wine with a hint of lick em stick with some grape on it (the candy) some lemon/citric acid.

taste is nicely acidic but not overopwering, some asian pear, spicy oak, some grape/wine acidity. a nice roundness to the flavor as nothing overpowers here. a bit of old oak and tobacco plays in the background. not funky really.

smooth mouthfeel, not too dry, a good amount of carbonation but not prickly. almost a creaminess.

this is just an extremely well balanced beer with nice rounded flavors that meld together. This is one of the finest American examples of what Belgians have been doing for a long time. Nice to have this relatively available as its made just about year round.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 At the sour tasting, part B, thanks Noam, pours yellow hazy with a small head, fresh aroma of honey, molasses, wine, brett, light spices, leaves , flavor of lemon, wood, brett, red wine, quite zesty and carbonated, medium to full bodied, nice 8/3/8/4/14[3.7] 

At a tasting, many thanks tomer, pours yellow to orange with a medium head, aroma of olives, brett, wet leaves, leather, wood, some honey and vinous notes, flavor is sour and dry with some lemon, apple vinegar, white wine, nice carbonation and light pleasant bitterness, medium to full bodied. Great Stuff 9/4/9/4/17[4.3]

at a tasting, many many thanks mom and dad, hazy lemon yellow colour, aroma of tropical fruits, lemon, unripe fruits, oak and butteriness,flavour of tropical fruits, chardonnay vinousity and that oak and butter in the back, mellow smooth sourness, light long sour aftertaste. Exquisitley smooth, mellow  and balanced brew, an amazing marriage of beer and wine.

On tap at the brewery.  This beer smells of lemon, oak, and sweetness.  The appearance is light golden and a thin white head.  Taste is very crisp and clean, with more sweet and mild sour than all out sour.   There are notes of citrus sour, and the oakiness of the chardonnay barrels gives some depth that is really nice.  It has a nice dry finish that is really refreshing.  Palate is dead on...light to medium body with a dry crisp finish.  Makes this beer as good as it is.  Overall, a really top notch sour from this wonderful brewery

Pours a cloudy golden hue with a huge, tight head that is slow to subside and leaves a generous amount of lacing on the glass.
Woody sour fruit. A little an ale is hiding deep in there. And a bit of a yeast can be barely noticed. A little fusel - fermented hot?
Sweet on the tip of the tongue, sour on the back and a little rough on the throat. The sourness definitely dominates and drowns out some of the aromas I picked up earlier. A little woodiness is present, but not much. After a few sips the sourness dies down on the taste and the underlying ale can be perceived, if ever so slightly. A little sweetness starts in at this stage.
High carbonation makes it a little thinner than it ought to be. The sour bomb lingers on for, what seems like, forever. Nice. A little on the dry side, due to carb level and sourness I would imagine.
Very quaff-able. I dont think I would have too much of a problem drinking this all evening. Well blended flavors make it a real crisp, palate-pleasing drink. If not for the ABV this could be a great session beer. Excellent.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2013 Comparison of Batch 1, 3, 4, and 5 12/4/10

Batch 5-fair bit of hops, juicy, hints of soap with notes of leathery brett up front. som dry oak, dustry, very light chardonney wine flavor.  juicy dry oak, bright white grapes and slightly sour with a fairbit of grassy hops and some juicy citrus.

Batch 4-more sublte than 5, chardonney comes out slightly more and the hops are much more mild.  flavors of integrated oak, white grapes, light brett presence and faint hops.

Batch 3-the hops have faded but the flavors are soft well integrated and subtle.  the chardonney barrels really make a bright presence, juicy white grapes as the brett comes in behind.  the brett is slightly sharp but still leans towards subtlty with some lemon and soft peach flavors in the back.

Batch 1-the brett has started to dominate and take over, the chardonney and juicy wine flavors have become much light and the sweetness now resides behind and underneath the strong brett presence.

**************************

Batch 004X4 reveiwed 3/1/10

A-pours a pale golden yellow color with a thin bubbly head, 2-3 full fingers, holding strongly to the side of the glass.

S-nice notes of oak and hints of vanilla start off this funky aroma. Wild yeasts take over giving it a fair amount of funk, sour grapes and green apples, notes of lemon zest and grass at the finish

T-tart cherries, sour white grapes, and notes of lemon zest are followed by a biscuity malt base. the oak is very faint in the taste as it comes in towards the back.

M-this is extremely smooth and crisp throught, sharp finish and very dry. medium body with a slight warming from the alcohol in the back with a lot of carbonation.

D-this is very sweet and tart. it brings huge flavors and an interesting taste from the barrel aging. Another intersting brew from RR.

draft at Russian River, Great great beer. medium golden pour. Fruity tart & somewhat acidic aroma. White wine, tartness, acicdic, lemon, brett. not overly agressive with the tartness but just enough. Very good
Bottle. Pours a hazy yellow with a big white head. Aroma of perfume, chardonnay, barnyard funk. Flavor is tart, dry with a nice floral flavor and some residual sweetness. Very nice.

Batch 002, Pours a hazy golden body with glimpses of orange and a thin white head. Beautiful lacing in the glass. Flavors are complex with some light fruit, green apples, pears, green grapes, horse blanket notes, lots of funky wood flavors and the nose is almost all brett with some malty sweetness hanging around. As with the batch 002 Supplication I drank the night before, the balance of these beers is amazing. Sour, yes, but not over done, with a wonderful woody balance that keeps the light malts from getting too watery. This was refreshing, bright, and one of the best things I ever decided to cellar.

The aroma is filled with crisp citrus and oak. Russian River excels when producing sour ales, this is truly one of the best. It has a pale golden color and the white head resembles snow. Though champagne is present in the taste, beer is the foundation. Keep an open mind while sampling it, this may not be for traditional beer drinkers though. Overall this is a good example of a sour ale and well worth purchasing again.

Draft at Falling Rock, Denver.  Filtered golden-tan with a creamy white head.  Harsh funky lemon sour notes under some creamy malt.  Pretty nice, sort of incorporates a the funky sourness quite well into the malt base.  Medium bodied, very drinkable for the ABV.  Tart and refreshing.  Lemon funk notes dominate.  Superbly melllow, great stuff.  The white wine really becomes apparent the more its sipped.  White wine and beer hybrid.

From bottle, courtesy of dpjuart. Great lactic sour oaky nose, funky with chardonnay and mild hops. Well balanced aroma, tart and ethereal. Clear golden with pillowy white lacing head. Medium light body with medium carbonation. Starts tart and lactic with oak. Light sweetness with a bit of chardonnay. Just a great sour character, with great balance of sour and oak notes. Very quenching and not overly harsh. Very nice sour.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2011 Pours clear golden with a thick frothy white head. Aroma is aour funk and citrus. Flavor is a nice balance of saurkraut tang and sweetness. A great mineraly citrus character. Dry, light and refreshing. Pretty tasty. Finishes very very dry. Delicious.
The last of the Russian Rivers we brought home from SF. So sour and yeasty. Very different from the fruity ones.

Bottle 375ml batch 003, thanks to Glouglouburp. Beautiful peachy-gold body, lasting white head, nice ring and heavy lacing. Aroma of tropical fruits (pinneaples, citrus and passion fruits), some farmhouse, wet hay, brett and musty wood but not in excess. Close to perfect. Taste is sour upfront, some bitterness with a moderatly sweet fruity finish for the style. Its all about balance. Grapefruit skin and lemon rind, white wine and woody flavors. Awesome beer, I was tempted to give it a perfect score in every class because its beautiful balance and drinkability. The only flaw would be its sweetness. As I our the remaining lees, the pinneaples seems to be more present. Damn, this rating is getting incoherent. Lets stop this.

Bottle. batch 05x2E. golden pour, little white head that fades quick.  bubbly, similar to champagne.  Taste of lemon, tart, and funk.  Very quick to finish because the tart smacks you in the face and disappears.

Bottle pours hazy yellow with a white head.  Aroma shows notes of lemon, oak, green apple, and leather.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of white vinegar, funk and light peach. Extremely well balanced with a creamy palate and crisp acidity.

Appears hazy royal gold with ample pure white fluffy, lacy-beyond-belief head that crowns the glass and stays there as a half-finger cap. Aroma is of sour melon, wood (from the oak I assume), funky yeast, floral notes, and lemon citrus. Smell keeps developing with time, with the lemon/flower scent coming through after the initial oak/melon. Taste is intoxicating, with sour light fruit initially, and a woody finish, with plenty of others in between, including yeast funk, white wine, and a tart carbonation kick throughout. Mouthfeel is fantastic, mainly due to that carbonation, as it rushes everything evenly around the palate. Beer is light while being well-bodied and leaves a nice dry coat around the mouth. Drinkability is really great for the style, probably because of how dry the finish is. This is a lot like a wine, and adds to it in so many different ways. Russian River just doesnt disappoint.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2011 Refreshing, mouth drooling monster of a wine beer.  Chardonnay butterscotch, ripe white grapes, brown sugar, and a little tart citrus dominate.  A little wheaty malty undertones here and there just to keep it good and full bodied.  Disappears off the palate almost like champagne.

Draft at Obriens. Dark yellow hue with frothy white head and lacing. Nose is Chardonnay grapes and oak, light fruits, Bret funk and sourness. Flavor is light fruit up front balanced out by Bret funk, the sour profile is subtle but consistent, oak accents present as well, finishes dry and sour.  Light body, spritzy carbonation, watery texture. A very light sour ale with prominent Chardonnay features, well-done but definitely not for everyone.

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Pours translucent golden with a slight trace of orange, and a tightly bubbled, soft, craggy white head. Beautiful spider-web lacing down the sides of the glass. Aroma packs a nice floral wallop; dry hops, Belgian candied sugars, wheat, honey, traces of lavender and chamomile, and sharp, farmhouse funk. Body is full and well carbonated with a somewhat dry, extremely tart palate. Finishes quick, powerful, and dry. Very similar to fine champagne, yet much more sophisticated, nuanced, and refined.
Bottle. Pours a golden yellow with a short white head. Sour aroma with lemons, apples, grapes and some funk. Flavor is nice and sour with green apples, white grapes, lemons and some notes of oak.

Poured into a tulip. Batch 004x5.

4.5 A: Hazy golden straw color. Two fingers of pillowy white head. Most of the head falls quickly, but the last 1/2 finger sticks around for a long time. Plenty of lacing.

4.5 S: Brett funk for sure, but way more funk that just the brett alone. Tons of barnyard funk with hay and horse blanket. Healthy fruity tartness backs up the funk. Oak tones linger. Very nice.

5.0 T: Brett barnyard funkiness again. Tart, but not overly so, fruitiness including wild orchard red apples and peaches. Straw and peppery yeast. Oak hits the spot as well. It does have plenty of chardonnay aspects as well. Excellent.

4.5 M: Lighter medium mouthfeel. Bubbly carbonation is perfect. Smooth with no major flaws. Tangy tartness on finish.

5.0 D: The most drinkable wild and one of the most drinkable of any brew. I could sip this all night long. I wish my bottle was 3L.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-08-2010 01:22:28

bottle(thanks to Mlunger12) at my leaving FL throwdown(17Dec10)pours light yellow with a thin white head.  Loads of bubbles very champagne looking.  Aroma is floral with only thin tart lemon hints that this is a sour.  Flavor is again floral with chamomile and dandelion ending with a sour finish that seems equal parts vinous and wild yeast.  Very good stuff.

Pours a hazy yellow with a small head. The aroma has some buttery tonewith some solid apples. The flavor has green apple, butter, spice, horse blanket, and à hint of soap. Not bad, but this is the weakest link of the sour series.

Bottle. Pours clear yellow, thin, non-persistent white head; spotty to poor lacing. Nose is big funk, white grape skin, green apple skins, light sweatiness, and musty straw. Flavours are balanced, white grapes, rather reminds me of Cascades The Vine. Sourness isnt extremely overt, just light and balanced with the rest of the flavours; Lemons and horseblanket come out to play, nice sherbety palate. Damn, the Firestone Walker 14 is a tough act to follow, but this is pretty killer.

Batch 05x01E. Opened on 01.09.2011. 

Pours slightly cloudy, straw-golden-bodied with a soft half-finger head that settles to a thin film-like covering. Bubbles stream upwards to the surface.

Temptation frontloads with tons of lemony citrus, green apples, green grape, and orange, following with a light, dry woodiness. The brett funkiness takes a backseat, complementing the citric acid and Chardonnay at the fore. Very clean, pungent, and rich. 

Taste is much of the same, leading with lime, green apple, and pear which lets way to hay and bretty earth notes. You can just let this sit in your mouth and let it breathe to feel its progression. Theres the tiniest hint of clove, but most of it is swallowed up by the tanginess. Temptation, as is usually the case in life, ends with a slight whimper - theres a bitterness coalescing with an almost-mute, odd mineral note. Otherwise, this one has a lot of finesse.

Silky, halfway-between-light-and-medium-bodied with above average carbonation. Dangerously drinkable, with just a hint of dryness on its finish. Delicious.
Pours a nice golden blonde color, nice subtle head. Taste of fruit, oaks, peaches are prominent and so are nectarines. Nice finish, dry and tart. Delicious beer. Russian River does not disappoint.

Impressive clear golden color with a nice foamy white head.

Some nice funky & fruity aromas abound.  These develop more in the taste with sour pear & apple  being the dominant flavors alongside the yeasty funk.

Bubbly and almost champagne like, it has a similarly dry/bitter finish.  Very interesting and well done beer.  Would LOVE to drink more of this.  EXCELLENT!

Bottle; Pour is clear golden - nice white head. Chardonnay and Oak on the nose - a light fruit ester, oak, chardonnay round out the flavor profile with that funk you were expecting, as well. I was perhaps least impressed by this one during the sour tasting. Not to say that it doesnt work well, but I find the white wine too dominating and limiting for this brew.

bottle.  Pours clear golden yellow with white head.  Sour aroma, white wine, sour white grape, peach nectar.  Flavor mimics aroma, and is less sour than the other russian rivers, making it more palatable.  I feel the consecration or supplication would be better with food, like red meat, while this is nicer to sip on its own.  Sour fruit flavors, with chardonnay on the finish.  Nice.

Bouteille 75cl, batch 004X2
Couleur dorée comme les blés avec une très légère brume, le col est blanc et effervescent.
Arôme, de suite je note le chêne français/aigreur ainsi que des raisins verts laissant échapper un nez de vin blanc.

En bouche, pas mal daigreur et vinaigre qui font ressortir le chêne et laissent une fine note dépice/bois. Ce mélange en tonneau est subtile et laisse percevoir de bonnes notes de vin Chardonnay; raisin vert avec en du zeste de citron. Lusage de Brettanomyces donne un fini aigre mais qui est tout a fait dans le style de cette bière et reste appréciable au palais.
Le niveau de levure est moyen et renforce ce goût de Brett, au palais la bière est bien effervescente laissant passer un aspect de levure type champagne.
Pours a hazy yellowish orange with a billowing white head. The aroma consists of vinegar, horse blanket, grass and funk.The flavor is sour and the palate is very dry

Pours clear and golden with thin white head; lively carbonation. Nose of Bret, pear, green apple and white grape. Taste of lemon, oak, light fruit and white wine. I enjoy the sour and white wine combination more than expected. Well done Vinny. Nice, complex finish.

Huge thanks to my Secret Santa for this!Pours slightly cloudy orange. Smells really nice - wood and champagne, with some sour notes, too. Flavor is oak, white wine, and a nice background of funk and musty, basement notes. Finishes with a small but still surprising bitter note. Really good stuff! Thanks again!

terrible smell, but has a sweet bitter taste, definately can taste the chardonnay casks it was aged in would qualify this as a sweet wine before i would coin it beer, but still pretty good wine hahaha
bottle thanks to bhensonb.  poured hazy yellow.  aroma was lemon, vanilla, brett, and oak.  flavor was lemon, oak, tart, and sour.  body was light with high carbonation and a dry finish.

Appearance: clear gold under a white head which gathers in the middle while lace crawls up the sides of my glass. Swirls with a bubbly head and spread-out lace.

Nose: sour and golden. Sourdough breads. Lemon drops with a hint of sugar though far more sour and puckery than sweet. White grapefruit with soft white pith.

Palate: lemon drops from start to finish. Puckers the mouth almost immediately with a Berliner Weisse quality, most interestingly enough. Lemon infused sourdough bread. A bit simple but very refreshing. Bottle-conditioning lends to a zippy zesty playful mouthfeel which complements the lemon and scattering of white grapefruit. Slowly dries tongue and sides of cheeks.

Final Thoughts: I was initially expecting far more complexity, but she is a soured golden and thus just about right. Little evidence of farmhouse funk or the wood she was aged in lends to the overwhelming vinous sour brightness that put a smile on these lips.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2013 On tap at Russian River, pours a cloudy dull copper with a small white head. Aroma brings out big time Chardonnay barrels, light wild yeast, and some light zesty fruits. Flavour is similar and very complex, bringing out notes of citrus zest, prominent white wine barrels, and wild funky yeast notes. Awesomely complex, with a very dry, zesty, vinous palate. Classic pinnacle American sour.

Pours light gold.  Nose is sour, oaky.  Moderately sour on the palate. OK, but not my thing.

From sample pour at local December 2010 tasting.
Nice clear golden, interesting and funky. Its not quite as sour and crazy as I expected from the rest of the RR sours. It has a bit of oaky taste to it, some sour grape stuff. Great stuff.
Tap at the source.  Clear dark yellow, edge head, great lacing.  Aroma of sourdough bread.  Taste is sour up front, and on the sides.  Good character, dry and slightly bitter finish.

Bottle, Cads mon the beezer leave at 6 to drink Mikkeller tastings. 

Stunning wild yeast aroma, lots of lemons, sourness, funky beats, nice carbonation, fuzzy heart-warming stuff, bready yeast, texture, very composed and well balanced. A sour and dry and lemony finish. Great to try this. Rather excellent adaptation of the sour ale which Belgians are so commanding at. Nice to see an American brew give them a run for their money.

On tap at the brewery in August 2009.

A: Pours a cloudy pale amber color with a large white head of foam.

S: Lots of tarness and sourness here, with a little bit of the oak coming through.

T: Lots of sourness coming into some tartness and a little bit of citrus.

M: Quite tart, fairly full for the style. Good amount of carbonation.

D: Drinkable for the style, but not my favorite of Russian Rivers Belgian styles.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 09-24-2009
0.375l - Yellow liquid, no head, sour nose.  Palate was nice, not as layered as others in the style.  The chardonnay character did bring something nice to the party.

This poured a cloudy yellow color with a white head. Aroma was of sour lemons, slight funk and belgian yeast. Flavor was medium sourness upfront, followed by belgian candi sugar and belgian yeast and wine notes, and then finally ending with moldy cheese and funk. Great beer, not nearly as sour as some of the other Russian River beers ive had, but in a good way

Straw yellow pour with a loose white head and a lot of active carbonation. Almost like champagne.  Aroma is sour funk a bit of barnyard some oak notes.  Flavor is tart, light, chardonnay and oak are apparent.  Oakiness lends some nice body but the star of the show is the brett funkiness.  Really amazing beer.

Bottle from Capones. Pours a hazy bright yellow. Small clingy head. Aroma is sharp, musty, and champagne. The taste is sour of course, but definitely has chardonnay or champagne hints. The Brett does wonders on this ale. A nice sipper.
On tap.  Golden color with white head.  Sour/acidic aroma.  Medium body.  Nice sourness with chardonnay notes in the flavor.  Very unique and delicious.

Sampled at a Freetail release, bottle share. A generous soul offered up a 750ml for general consumption.  Poured a hazy/cloudy dark straw colored body with a bit of off-white, fizzy head.  Aromas of white wine, sourness, tart, acidic and lemons.  Flavors are funky, sharply acetic, sour apple, dusty and herbal.  A very complex palate that should probably be re-sampled under better conditions.

Aroma of Chardonnay, tart apple, sour cherry. Appearance is cloudy gold with white head. Flavor matches the nose- starts out sour and goes tart, finishing dry and vinous. Palate is very bubbly. Great stuff. Like drinking a gueuze\sour ale combo.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2012 Bottle @ home. Glad to finally try this again! Pours a hazy golden orange appearance with a white head and a bit do sediment. Delicious bretty characteristics in the nose with a lot of pineapple, mango, and vanilla along with notes of dry white wine, light oak, some acidity, and a light sourness. Big tart pineapple, guava, lemon bretty, oaky vanilla, pleasantly tart, mildly sour, delicious tropical fruity flavor. Lingering pineapple tartness. Beautiful stuff that kind of reminds me of Bambic.
