Tasted 10/8/10. 375ml bottle. Filtered with a golden hue. Spiraling white head. Aromas of apples, earth, cranberries and tart cherries. Medium to full bodied with a very tart and bitter palate. Flavors of various fruit; apples and cranberries and raspberries. Nicely soured and very solid!

Shipped to me by my wife on a trip to Portland. Sampled from a 750 ml corked brown bottle this beer poured a very cloudy yellow-golden color with a large foamy yellow-white head that lingered and produced some lacing. The aroma was bitter, tart, tangy, musty, bretty and citric. The flavor was very sour and tart with light must and bret and notes of bread, pepper, strong lemon and faint oak. The finish was long, very tart and sour with lingering lemon and must. Medium body. Interesting.

Batch 004. Pours clear pale gold with a foamy white head. Aroma of sour apple, unripe berries, lemon, floral aspects, a very pleasent sourness. There is also enough banana and clove to let me know its a Blonde but without being the main focus. Taste has more of a sharp sourness and lots of juicy malt. Medium body, sharp carbonation. As the beer warms it gets more mellow as far as texture and carbonation with more sourness coming through. So good.
Pours a clear yellow with long-lingering small bubbles. Smells of a sour Sauvignon or maybe a full-bodied rose. lingering sour tastes with light  aftertaste of apricots.

375mL bottle batch 05X1E pours golden/straw with thin white head. Aroma is sour and tart, grapes, yeast, oak, and Bret. Flavor is sweet and tart with a nice overall sourness from the Bret, slight pepper, citrus, chardonnay evident on the dry finish. Very nice, I liked the Consecration more but this is still stellar.
bottle at home .. golden amber ... rising bubbles ... light lemon ... light barnyard nose ... ligh dry lermon peel bitterness ... resfreshing clean and not to sour ... quite like this for what it is.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2011 Golden pour, thin white head.  Sour white grape aroma with vanilla, a little funk.  Moderately sour apple and white grape flavor, lots of smooth creamy vanilla and oak, mild brett funk.  Very interesting.

Tap @Taphouse Grill, Bellevue. Hazy dark gold pour with a white head leaving a moderate lace. Midway between a Damnation and a Supplication, this Belgian Sour starts sour but shows a solid hoppiness in the middle and a medium body that is rarely found in sours. Lemon, apple, wine and a faint hint of ripe banana. Gorgeous, one of my favorite Belgians!

(375ml bottle-Batch 3).  Pours hazy golden color with thin white head.  Active carbonation. Aroma of lemon, pepper?, and Brett.  Taste is sour with a little sweetness. Thin bodied with a thin/creamy (from the head).  Finish has a gentle, but prominent, white wine aspect.  Seems tart like I ate some Smarties. This is a nice beer and would be especially refreshing in the hot Arizona summer months.

RR dinner @ Monks:  Poured a golden yellow color with a thin head.  The aroma was oak, wine, apple and sourness.  The flavor was sweet and tart, bitter apple, wood/oak, and the nice dryness from a Chardonnay wine.  Overall, a great dinner beer if paired right.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2010 [clocks in at my 200th Cali rate, but really its back logged]  002 and 003 sampled same night thanks to Holdenn!!! 002 roma is nicely sour with equal part funk, 003 is more of a clean pool water aroma.  Both pour a very clear bright blonde with spritzy larger fizzy carbonation.  002 is sharply lactic, nicely acidic, light cheesy aged hops, 03 is more oaky, vanilla, cashews, nutty.  Body is spritzy clean carbonation, 03 seems more attenuated.

Picked up a 375ml bottle at Best Damn Beer Shop in San Diego, California, and managed to wait a couple weeks before trying it...  This bottle came from batch #3.  Pours a clear, golden straw color with a small white head.  The nose here is very subtle--almost faint, but I do pick up on sour, champagne-like aromas combined with just a bit of yeasty funk coming through.  Taste is interesting; winey, of course, but also incorporating apple and lots of fruit flavors with a peculiar, woody, funky bitterness  that enters momentarily.  I have a lot to learn about sours, so perhaps its just inexperience talking here, but I really like that this beer seems a little milder and more balanced than some of the other sours Ive tried.  Its comparatively light and drinkable, with nice carbonation and a fizzy mouthfeel.  Very good.

Absolutely amazing beer. Not a big fan of the tart, and sour flavors imparted by the lambics and american wiild-style ales but this was beautifully balanced. aging in white wine barrels truly blurs the line between a fine wine and fine beer. again, another success from russian river.

Serving: 750 ml. bottle from Hi-Time Wine Cellars. 
Aroma: The nose has a good bit of oak, Chardonnay, grass, and oddly enough what I would describe as pickle. 
Appearance: It pours a hazy gold with a foamy white head.  Good head retention. 
Taste: The first thing that strikes me about the flavor is the noticeable back bitterness.  There is a good bit of oak, some grass, a light honey that reminds me of mead and a nice tartness from the brett. 
Palate: Light in body with a high carbonation leading to a very clean finish. 
Overall: I really enjoyed the varying dimensions this brew brought to the table.  To a degree the bitterness was a bit too aggressive for my taste, but I would still highly recommend this brew.
10/9/10.  Thanks, Coleman!  750mL bottle.  Creamy winey aroma with a good hint of wood.  Big sour flavor that is surprisingly mild and clean with hints of wood and white wine.  Very nice!

10.08.10 375 ml bottle. 
Cork opens with huge pop, pours clear golden straw color with a whispy white head that slowly fades to the glasses edge. The nose is straw, crisp white grapes, Chardonnay tannic notes, Brett, and some saison like peppery notes. Taste is initially crisp white grapes, Chardonnay and slight pepper, transitions into a nicely soured lactic acid (not overpowering), Brett yeast (slight taste), and more white grape. What a wonderful sour ale. My second favorite from RR (behind Consecration). Glad I bought another to cellar. Cant wait to try Consecration, Supplication, Temptation, Redemption, Beatification, and Damnation all next to eachother in about a year or two.

Draft at the pub. Just shy of clear gold with wispy white froth. Pleasing But restrained cedar and lemon aroma. Powerful but measured crisp sour dominates more vinous congeners. Incredibly "clean" for a naturally soured beverage -- theres just a hint of complex phenol. Dangerously drinkable for 7%, like a biggish Berliner weisse. Up there with Rodenbach Grand Cru in contention for my favorite sour.

Pour is a hazy light orange. Little head. Aroma is a nice sour cherry funk. Some minor wine and grape hints. Flavor is so nice and sour. Really incredible cherry and grape funk. So nicely balanced and smooth.
Clear blon with a large rocky head, which decrease quickly. Aroma is BRETT !!!! Light body and soft carbonation. In mouth is sour, white wine, and fruity. Good one !

The pour is a very hazy, gold color with a fairly small, white, fizzy head which actually leaves a fully lasting, frothy layer and soapy lace rings.  The nose is pleasant with a nice balance between brett tartness, oak notes, and sweet; nice brett funk and tartness, lightly spicy, light doughy notes, wet cork and oak, faint vanilla, and some muscat grapes.  The flavor is still full of brett funk, wet cork and oak, faint vanilla, still a bit spicy, but the lemon tartness begins to take over and dry out the finish; faint doughy notes and grapes in the middle.  The palate is nice with a lively carbonation, medium body, and a creamy mouthfeel but drying in the finish.  The finish is long, tart, but not quite puckering, drying, and funky with lemon and similar wet oak and cork notes.  An interesting beer pairing a Golden ale with brett and chard barrels but I had a hard time finding much of the base beer with everything else being a bit overshadowing.  I think the combination of brett, chard barrels, and Golden ale  worked well together, I just think that the brett could have been a bit less or the ABV could have been higher to accentuate the base beer a bit more.  RR always does exceptional work and this is certainly not my favorite, but still quite nice and unique.

Bright yellow appearance and fairly light. Citrusey smells. I got a lot of lemon and floral notes in my initial sips. Pretty full mouthfeel. A little like white wine. Very interesting. This is far from a session-able beer. At least for my tastes. But thats not the goal with a beer like this. I might not have another, but Id recommend this beer to a friend who wanted to explore beer into this style.
Bottle thanks to Pollack. Pours cloudy champagne yellow with white head. Nose of funk, oak, wine and champagne yeast. Taste of champagne yeast, oak, wine, dried citrus. Mild tartness.

Thanks to DaveJanssen for supplying me with this fantastic brew.

Poured from the 1pt. 9.4 oz. bottle into a tulip glass.

The color is a glowing orange/yellow with a good amount of carbonation and three fingers of foamy white head. Some thick lacing on the glass.

The smell is funky at first. Some banana and a touch of clove. There is a green grape flavor that touches lightly on the nose and then comes back to let the sweet malt flavor shine.

The taste is like a jolly rancher or a sweet tart, very sweet and sugary that is sings in my mouth and brings about visions of green grape fun dip. It is a roller-coaster of flavors that hit me over and over and I really am amazed at how complex this beer is. Wow will not suffice.

The feel of this beer is light and really tart. The wild feel is welcoming and sweet to the taste buds. If you have this beer it is a pleasure of the senses. It really is what most brewers dream of achieving.

I loved everything about this beer. The wine like aroma, the nice golden pour with the small head and the flavor which is quite different from most beer. It has a very sour bite and yet a fruity and mellow taste.  The finish is very dry and refreshing. Nice funk in there too. Just an outstanding brew.
yellow pour, bretty citrus arouma. nice funk and vineous citrus sour. Lovely dry finish.
Pale yellow straw color. Sour, musky, wine aroma characteristics. Floral, lemon, grass, white wine flavors. Smooth clean finish. Wow, what a great beer. Absolutely delicious. Very nice.

Clear blonde golden pour light white head ... sour and wine like aroma .... taste of oaky wine and sour fruits .... grapes cherries very sour and bitter .... lots of bret ... thinner than other sours from RR and dangerously drinkable with a bitter dry finish ... too much of this makes you regular!

Bottle.  Pours a rich golden hue with two-plus fingers of white fluffy foam.  Aroma is of sweet white grapes, oak, and sour musk.  Taste is initially more dark and sweet than sour, but then the barrels kick in, and light white grapes turn to a delicate sour flavor, far from overwhelming. A second taste confirms the unusual balance that this brew possesses.  It is indeed somewhere between a sour ale and a fine white wine,  full light light flavor and musky subtlety.  Really, the balance is incredible, though the lack of full-on sourness is, perhaps, a bit disappointing.  Still, about as high quality as it gets.

375mL bottle pour.  Body is medium golden color with a thin white head.  The leaves very little lacing.  Aroma is yeasty, hoppy, and a little sour.  Flavor is not overwhelmingly tart.  I prefer my sours with a smack-you-in-the-face sort of tartness, which this brew doesnt have.  Not my favorite RR sour, but its still an outstanding beer.

Draft at the brewery. This was my surprise favorite of our Santa Rosa visit. Ended up buying a few bottles to take home too. Just thinking about it makes my mouth water. Probably blurs the line between ale and wine more so than anything else I have tried...think Ill go open a bottle right now...

Bottle shared with Leafs93.  Pours a golden yellow color with a champagne like ultra thin white head.  Has a tart aroma with hints of yeast.  Has a sweet tart taste.  Crisp.  Very gentle bitters on the backend.  Excellent brew.
Pours hazy yellow with white head.  Aroma is brett funk, vinegar and citrus.  Taste is a tart citrus, nice and bitter with a sweet finish.  A great sour.
From bottle, golden-yellow ,fogging,thick head,tart and sour, lemon,i like it alot

~12 oz bottle courtesy of Josh.  Golden/straw colored pour, pretty much no head.  Im not too familiar with this style yet so its tough to pick out some of the individual notes, but the aroma and flavor both have the nice sour notes with a very dry finish.  The chardonnay notes definitely come through in the finish.  Very good beer, not sure it was worth such a high price.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of sour funk, citrus, oak, white wine and flowers.  Medium yellow\orange hazy hue with a small white head that mostly diminished and left little lace.  Flavor is medium sweet, tart, and finishes medium/heavy sour with a little spicy peppery kick.  Palate is medium bodied with average carbonation.  Overall a very nice ale that was both refreshing and complex.  Another delight from Russian River.
Pours pale yellow with a light head. Aroma is like apple cider. Flavor is white wine and cider, with a hint of malts somewhere in there. Very dry with quickly vanishing carbonation. Interesting.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2011 From 750ml bottle at Moeder Lambic Fontainas. Thanks Jean !
Appearance : Clear pale yellow with small head.

Aroma : Nice fruity and citrusy. Some funk with some oak. Slightly lactic.

Taste : Citrusy and tart. Some funk. Finish is quite tart.

Overall : Very nice beer. Awesome tartness. We had this one right before or after (cant remember) a glass of Cantillon classic gueuze from tap and both felt like they were in the same league. I had this one after a couple beers so my palate was not top shape. I need to re-rate someday. Awesome stuff.

Re-rate 110106 
750ml bottle shared by Ruth.
Aroma : Clean tartness Light brett.

Taste : Nice tartness with light bitterness. Citrusy and fruity. Great carbonation, very nice small bubbles.

Overall : Great lacing. Very nice brew. PRetty straight forward but very tasty. Exactly my kind of Sour. App 3 to 4. Over 18 t0 17. Total stays the same.

Beer from trade. Thx Kevin. Had both a temptation aged 12 month and 16 month, a batch 1 and 2. So this rating will somehow be a combination of those two experiences. The body on both is dark grain yellow with a nice hazyness, The crown on the 16 month version is more potent and massive and snow white. The nose is lactic with fresh peaches and hints of honey and a bit of vinegar. Its easy to drink and the 12 month version seem to be way more anonymous compared to the 16. mo that beats it on all levels. Its more sour and with a palate that is a bit more creamy and just more agressive but at the same time very balanced. Very nice brew.  The score is given for the 16 mo. My score for the 12 mo was one under on all positions...

750 ml brown bottle. Batch 004x3. Consumed July 2010. A translucent blonde beer with a good white head that starts to slowly fade. Aroma is lightly sour with obvious Brett notes, citric. The taste has a nice lemon juice like sourness that makes you lick your lips...crisp clean and very refreshing. This is a perfect summer drinking beer and is another great sour RR has in their portfolio

Sample at RBSG 10 grand tasting. Pours a slightly hazy blonde with a good head and some lace. The aroma is lemon pledge with some earthy and tart tones along with some barnyard. 
The flavor is sour cherries with a good earthiness and tart tones. The beer presents what seems to be a good deal of new oak. Reminds me a bit of gueze.

Had on draught at Russian River.  Pours golden blonde with a small white head and very nice lacing.  Aroma is strongly vinous with hints of oak, yeast, and acid.  Taste is amazingly complex with strong flavors of oak, chardonnay, malts, acetic acid, and the perfect amount of sourness.  An easier drinking sour than the Consecration and Supplication, but no less complex or enjoyable.  Worth $25/bottle?  Perhaps.  Worth it on tap straight from the source, any day.

Ive been on an American Wild Ale run here as of late, might as well review this one as well. 375ml bottle into Duvel tulip.

A - Pours golden in color with a fluffy white head that leaves a ton of sticky lacing behind. Lots of white fizzy bubbles remain along the top of the beer and along the edge of the glass.

S - Funky, sour, tart, and fruity. Not as "wild" as the Supplication or Consecration, but based upon the reviews and talk, I expected this to be less of a wild compared to other offerings by Russian River.

T - A really nice blend of fruity and tart/sour with a nice oaky finish. Actually, a little more wild then I would have expected, based on the nose. 

M - Light in body. A dry, champagne-like, finish. A very crisp beer that is refreshing as well. Lots of nice fizzy carbonation, perfect.

D - A super-drinkable wild. Even more so the the Supplication and Consecration, because its a little less "wild" and a little more "tame". This is my only bottle, must find/buy/trade for more.

Bottle. Pours hazy orange with a mild, white head. Aroma is lightly sweet with prominent sour fruit notes, lemon, oak and alcohol. Flavor is fairly sweet but gives way quickly to a very sour, tart character. Highly acidic and somewhat vinous. Light to medium in body with subtle carbonation. Finishes dry and sour. Very good beer.

Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy. 
Pours a very hazy light gold with fizzy white head. Aroma of brett, very sour with a bit of earthiness. Flavor is very much the same and acidic, unfortunately I do not get any of the wood notes. Mouth feel is light body with high fizzy carbonation. Overall, very good shit!!!!

Sampled at the brewpub. Pours lighter than you would expect, almost at the appearance of a pilsner but ice cold and a solid head on it. The flavor of the sour is so nice. The complexity but also the simplicity of the mouthfeel comes shining through. Great brew, they really do sour so well!
Love the blond, refreshing flavor and aroma, even a pleasant bit of pig urine.

Batch 3.  Poured into a Hill Farmstead tasting glass.  A big, fluffy, white head sits on top of a clear, golden-yellow body. Sudsy lacing down the glass. Lots of bubbling beneath the head. Looks beautiful!  Light barnyard funk and white wine grapes on the nose. Oak barrels come through nicely. Light citrus and a bit of earthy brett. Some sweet malts.  Sour white grapes and tart green apples on the tongue. The brett has really come through and given the flavor a nice dry and tart presence. Sweet malts linger in the background. The lacto is coming through nicely as well, giving off some good sourness, but brett is still the most dominant. Overall, lots of green apple and white grape pulled together nicely with brett.  The body is crisp, with a good amount of sour/tartness. Fairly smooth with spritzy carbonation and slight alcohol warmth. Quite dry, especially on the finish. The brett has done nice things to this beer. Less foamy than other Russian River wilds. Could be due to the age. I like it.  Highly recommended, especially with a bit of age.
375 bottle,  A world class sour in my book.  Pours yellow with medium to light head.  Very crisp and refreshing, a nice head.  Awesome sour beer!

750 mL bottle.  Batch 4x3.  Pours blond with a small white head leaving a bit of lacing on the glass.  Smells of oak and Belgian yeast.  Tastes of sour lemon and citrus with a but of yeast flavor.  Crisp finish.  Light bodied.  Delicious.

750 ml bottle from South Bay Drugs.  Pours a murky peach color with a big white head that foams up high and lasts at about a cm thick on the beer.  Aroma of sour lemon citrus, funky brett, tart green apples, vinegar, peach, vanilla, straw, and oak.  Flavor also has a lot of sour lemon citrus and brett funk, with notes of white grapes and tart apples, pears, peaches, vanilla, oak, grass, champagne, and farmhouse funk.  Medium-full bodied, prickly and crisp on the palate, with a lot of carbonation.  Awesome sour ale.

Batch 003. Ive been saving this back to enjoy with friends and family on a hot summer afternoon and got the chance this past Sunday. What a delicious brew, I had this right next to a batch 003 supplication. I loved them both but enjoyed this temptaion just a little bit more. Sour ale aged in chard barrels... yum! The only disappointment was how quickly the bottle emptied.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2012 Bottle split with pat at monks. Pours a bright hazy golden body with nice white lacing with lots of bubbly carbonation.  Mouthfeel is champagne. Notes of tart citrus, grape, sour, and some funk.
Another spot-on sour from Russian River.  They can do no wrong in my book.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2015 batch 004x5 into an oversized pinot noir wine glass

A: Pale straw-yellow body.. hazy, lively carbonation... half inch white head quickly subsides to a healthy skim... sheets of lacing are left behind.

S: Green apples, tartness, pear, oak... very nice... the brett and the barrels both come through here

T: Excellent! Much like the nose the tart green apples and pears dominate while an undercurrent of oak ... actually, this was reminiscent of the superior saison, fantome!

M: Smooth, relatively light body... massive tart finish lingers on the tongue before fading... great carbonation levels

O: Considering how tart this was, it was very drinkable... quite enjoyable and worth every penny.

Sour and slightly funky aroma, cirtrus, lemon.  Yellow hazy beer with a huge billowing and fluffy white head.  Flavor is tart, and matches aroma.  Not too funky...great refreshing summer beer.  Yeasty.  Alcohol barely noticeable.  Finishes dry.

Hazy golden color,. Oak, fresh flowers, Chardonnay, honey, oranges layered after layer in the nose. Sourness definetely present. Oaky flowers, oranges in mouth, Pickering sourness. Well balanced. Low hops. Smooth.  Oakiness really shines but never overwhelming. Lingering oaky finish with lots of oranges. Great depth. Wonderful. Drinks bigger than 7.25%.

(750ml Bottle - Batch 004) Pours a golden color with a white head. Smell is sour lemons with some funk, grapes, oak, and some spices. Taste is sour with lemons, apples, yeast, brett, and oak. Medium mouthfeel, medium carbonation, with a dry finish. Overall im glad I finally got to try this one.

This corked and caged bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a extremely large sized head of all foam finely sized white colored bubbles that were mostly lasting and left behind a very softly carbonated transparent yellow white colored body. The aroma was lambic like farm house and sour. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of tart and sour. An OK brew just nothing special and way over priced for my tastes.

Tap @ brewery.  Clear, apricot colored, small white head, sheets of lace.  Aroma of apple, white grape, and oak with light alcohol and earthy notes.  Smells "sour."   Not spoiled, but sour.  Body is med-full with a light zip of carb and a pretty wet finish, mouth-watering to boot.  Flavor is sour with apple, oak, a touch of lint  hops that carry throught to he finish.   Very nice.  A supper

Bottle.  Straw yellow pour, medium carbonation and a pleasant lemon citrus sour aroma.  Flavor is light barnyard funk, lemon (tons of awesome mellow lemon) and finished with an indescribable lingering grab your attention slightly sweet/sour aftertaste.  Solid sour and well worth the acclaim.

004X4  A straw yellow sour with a little white head.  The mouth is overrun with lip puckering sour notes, bret, tart citrus,  and fruit.  The finish kinda has a light white wine burn to it.  Overall I think its a great example of a sour, but definitely an acquired taste.

Bottle. Batch 4 x 4. Pours a straw yellow color with a light whtie fuffy head. The smell is more sour than the Consecration I had but with less funk aroma. Sour taste up front with a slightly bitter end like medicine. Strong Bret flavor profile. Light/medium mouthfeel.

Bottle shared by kestral.
Funky aroma, barnyard, apples. Some sourness, lambic-like citrus.

Nice pop with the release of the cork.  Healthy carbonation.  Golden yellow in the glass with a slight orange haze.  Slight oak with a near white wine tinge in the aroma.  Bitter sour with some sweet tart notes.  Definitely lower on the sour/funk/tart scale then either Supplication or Consecration.  I tasted a lot of white wine in the finish.  Quite the refined and enjoyable beer.
Im not sure if I can give this justice, except that its just a beautiful sour beer, with a touch of fruity sweetness to accent it. Beers like this epitomize what I love about the "style".

375ml corked & caged bottle, batch #003, courtesy of wavers1. thanks, baker! pours a gorgeous, hazy, peach-orange with a thick, bubbly, white head leaving delicate lacing through the whole glass. aroma is simply outstanding with huge, sour citrus notes of lemon zest and orange peel, musty brett funk, white vinegar, pepper, granny smith apples, and light barnyard with a touch of tart apricot, peach pit, and pineapple backed by mildly sweet notes of oak and vanilla like a good chardonnay. flavor is beautiful as well with a plethora of tart fruit notes including apricot, peach, lemon, pear, white grape backed by elegant notes of oak, vanilla, and light brett funk with a touch of dry, earthy, grass and florals on the finish. palate is medium bodied, prickly on the tongue, clean and crisp like a fine chapagne with a long, lingering, lightly tart, dry, fruity finish. overall, an absolutely world class sour ale. awesome!

750ml 2009 bottle received in a recent trade.

Appearance: Gorgeous frosted lemon body with a luciously frothy 2 finger white crown. Tons of retention and lacing. Seriously sexy!

Smell: Extremely nice mixture of tart lemon notes, pronounced brett, white wine / green grapes, and a hint of oak. Im even getting a slightly smokey charred note from the barrel.

Taste: This ones opens with a nice tartness and continues on to show its grape / wine barrel quality, then finishes with a beautifully dry lemon drop tartness. This is so nice and sour with brett woven seemlessly in between the sour notes! This is seriously well crafted and Im in awe of the brewmasters talent. Puts fresh Cuvee De Castleton to shame!

Mouthfeel: Light bodied and well carbonated but lacks a nice crispness or a nice softness!

Drinkability: Oh this one is acidic enough to limit my intake but its delicious every sip of the way.

Russian River is by far my favorite Brewery!

2/25/10 Batch 04x04 2009 750ml bottle aged for 6 months:

The flavor has lost a bit of its pungent citric goodness and the grapes are showing even more now.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-28-2009

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Very nice sour ale but nothing complex. Almost like an easy going cider with just a hint of leather. Pretty straightforward.

Bottled @ UDRM. The aroma has barnyard, wood, citrus. Clear, golden coloured beer with a white head. The taste is citric, has barnyard and oak. There is some carbonation. Very clean taste, crisp and nice balanced.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2012 reviewed from a lifetime of bottles, glasses and samples.  the subtle excitement of spying it on a chalkboard or staring straight at a bottle sitting on a shelf.  an impatient cork announces its presence and intentions.  it looks like a treasure.  the malt in the nose is pale, crackling grain chaff; dry with a small touch of wheat.  aroma acids are tangy, pungent, bright and zesty. esters are waxy, fruity, slightly fatty. it leans toward noticeable influence from brettanomyces, with a delicate but much appreciated touch of lacto and ethyl lactate. some acids seem high but their presence is welcome: on the palate theyre soft, tart and pungent. the malt department is pale, sun-dried cracked hulls with a wheat sweetness (honey and lemon). mid-palate is the lush exploding natural carbonation, finishing as it begun: extremely soft, expertly conditioned, brilliantly structured and absolutely refreshing to enjoy.  champagne comes close.

Sample from a big-ass bottle poured by Walt at DLD 2010. Pours hazy gold with a medium white head. Very crisp nose of sour grape, citrus and oak. Tart and spicy flavor with oak, grape and citrus character and a sour finish.
Had this one @ Unofficial Dutch Ratebeer Meeting. Golden colored brew. Sour aroma. Flavor is sour too. Not very impressed.

Bottle. [thank you after4ever]
... batch 003 ...
Pours hazy yellow-golden with an extremely lovely, creamy, weakly off-white head. Super duration - especially for a sour ale. Aroma is very pleasant, good brett, oak, green apples, light citrus, some calvados feel to it and good notes of green grapes. Great dry and slight creamy texture. Flavour is elegant, dry, tart, zesty, oak, light apple. Extremely well-balanced. Long, lingering, bretty, dry, light bitter, zesty and oaky aftertaste with light barnyard and funk. Lovely!

375 ml bottle courtesy of Floydster. Batch 003. Thanks for the opportunity to try this beer..one of the priorities on my wants list! Poured into my snifter.

A- Body is a translucent golden yellow color. Pours with a solid 2-3 finger foamy white head. Leaves a lot of lacing behind in the glass and some film. When held up to the light one can see that this brew is uniform in cloudiness.

S-Nose is definitely there-but much softer than other sours I have experiences. The main characters are sour and salty-which I guess can be associated with vinegar-but I am getting more of an acidic sourness associated with a saltiness independent of that. Behind this all is a subtle sweetness that balances it all out.

T-Taste upfront is somewhat subtle and offers some tartness but there is enough of a presence of oak and granny smith apple (both tart and sweet components) flavors in the background to balance it out. The tartness comes trough some more for the finish but it is never unbearable or extreme in any way as there are some oaky characteristics that comes through as well. The finish is very clean as nothing lingers on the palate unless you lick your lips and get the moderately tart experience all over again... but I would not describe it as dry...because though there is a slight alcohol warmth it doesnt hinder the beers taste.

M-Low to medium carbonation and body that has yeasty, phenolic, acidic, salty, dry, and moist components (hard to explain but something one needs to experience).

D- This is an awesome sour/American Wild Ale by Russian River and something that I wish I would have had as a precursor to Deviation, Issabelle, and Beatification as those were all much more tart than this brew. A 375 ml serving of this is perfect and offers a lot of complexity and a great tasting experience. Russian River clearly does a great job with their sours and this one is a very balanced one. This is in its current state, IMO, the perfect introduction to sours.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-14-2009 02:58:36

Bottle @ RB meeting by Joes. A clear dark yellow colored beer, with a white head. The aroma is fruity with a light sourness with some malts. The taste is fruity of citrus. The are malts with notes of wood. The aftertaste is sweet with some bitter.

Hazy yellow with medium head. Sour, acidic aroma of must, wood, lemon zest, and sour funk. Flavor is puckering. Like a funky lemon juice being squeezed into your mouth. Slight oaky finish. Nice, but simple
Vibrant gold with a average white head. Aroma is of funk, lots of wood, sour, hay, straw. Taste is sour, funky, light lemon, and wood. Nice and dry.

Bottle at Dutch RB meeting, thanks for sharing joes! Pours an almost clear yellow color with a thin foamy white head. Aroma of brett, leather and blue cheese. Flavor is sour, yet quite mild with simple bretts and some spices. Sour finish. Slightly disappointing simple brew.

750ml Bottle. Batch 004X4.  Good vapor after the pop that showed some subtle funk right from the beginning.  Pours a straw color with lots of bubbles and a minimal layer of head.  Nose smells like musty lemons and hints at the tartness of the beer.  Also has an aroma of sour granny smith apples, chardonnay grapes and oak.  Brett comes in strong on the first sip with its usual barnyard funkiness and slowly gives way to a tart lemon zest flavor.  Body is somewhat thin with a high level of carbonation that makes the tart character of the beer stand out.  The finish lingers and is dry, crisp and lip smackingly sour. This really is a lighter sour that is more delicate than than other Russian River sours.  Only knock on this one for me is that there isnt much underneath the tart kick, was expecting some other flavors to stand out more and maybe a stronger malt profile.  That said this is still an excellent although pricey beer that gets better as it warms.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2010 Batch 002 from a 6 liter bottle at the Pizza Port Belgian beer party. This one pours a light and hazy golden yelowish-orange color topped by a small hed of white foam that slowly settles to a thin film. Thin sheets of lacing are left behind on the glass. The aroma is really nice showing a medley of sour lemons, chardonnay grapes, funky brett, oak, an vanilla. The nose really hints at the tartness in this one. The flavor follows with the brett showing first and adding some signature funky bitterness to go with the sour lemons and citrus fruit. The chardonnay barrels add some vinous character along with some vanilla from the oak to help balance out the sourness. The sourness isnt overpowering, but all the flavors are integrated perfectly. Medium full bodied with tingly carbonation and a nice dry, citrus finish. This is a very well crafted sour that is as refreshing as it is delicious.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2012 (Bottle) Pours hazy yellow to pale golden. The aroma holds light fruit (soft tropical/peach and mild citric), mouldy wood and light horse blacket/barnyard-like brett. Tiny phenolic and vanilla-ish. Maybe a touch of coconut. Clean malt base. The flavour is dry and near medium acidic. Nice balanced with notes of fruits, brett and citrus. Good malt base in the flavour as well. The mouthfeel is light tart and clean with light carbonation. Citric finish. Medium bodied.

Batch 2.  375 ml. Nice cork pop. Pale yellow and hazy. Nose is very bright, spunky, tart and citrusy.  Taste is relatively mellow, with lemon, citrus, tartness, all appearing. Very carbonated. Excellent.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: On tap at the brewpub. Hazy golden with a thin white head. Nice lacing. Aroma-sour, oak,  malt. Taste-tart, apricot, old wood, super complex, chardonnay, no sweetness. Very dry, lingering funk/ sourness. Slick mouthfeel. Almost hard to describe, excellent beer.

Bottle thanks to MaltoMeal. Pours a cloudy gold with the slightest amber hue and a nice white head that laces a bit. Aroma is has notes of green apple, some wheat notes a bit of barnyard funk and some tartness. Flavor builds in tartness with apples at the finish and funk and dough at the beginning.

Big white head. Hazy yellow body. Green apple barnyard and leather aroma with grainy lemony notes. Dry-sweetish-acidic apple leather and barnyard taste with peppery sugary notes. Mid-bodied. Intensely acidic aftertaste with apple and sugary leather notes. Cool, unusual, and very nice. (0.75l bottle shared by kestral.)

batch 004 in 750ml. pours clear straw yellow with large white head. aroma is fruity, oak, sweetness from the chardonnay barrels. drinks mild tart upfront lending to juicy fruits and lemon zest an finishes dry. fantastic offering.

Bottled, thanks vode! Hazy yellow brown color. Dry tart aroma with lemon, grapefruit. Dry grapefruity and lemony flavor with some bready bread crust notes. Very sour, tart and dry, still very enjoyable and drinkable. The mouthfeel is dry yet oily. My kind of beer!

(bottle, shared by MatSciGuy, thanks!) Pours light yellow with a white head that retains. Aroma is really nice and is composed of lemon peel, lemon custard, funk, earth, oak, and some hay as well. The taste has some tannins, oak, mustard seed, minerals, and a bit of cheesy funk to boot. Mouthfeel is medium and carbonation is lively. A really well done sour, which is hardly surprising considering who its brewed by.

bottle, batch 004x1, a nice hazy golden orange pour with tight white foam, aromas of sour yeast, oak, white wine, some dustiness, flavors are sour, bitter, dry german white wine with a funky horse crabapple bite to it, nice lingering finish

12.7 oz bottle poured into a tulip.  Pours a light amber/gold color with frothy white head, and vigorous carbonation shooting up the sides of the glass.  First thing that hits you from the aroma is grapes and oak, very much a wine character.  Also a tart yeasty funk, which gets more sour as the beer warms and airs out.  Taste is minor sweetness with tart bite.  Mouthfeel is very crisp and carbonated, body is light/medium.  Overall, very much like a champagne, very crisp and flavorful.  Great!!

On tap at the Falling Rock in Denver. Pours a mostly clear, golden body with a creamy, white head that dissipates slowly and leaves loads of lacing. Gorgeous beer. Aroma is sweet and tart. Not over the top sour, which is nice. Some sweet citrus, apples, white grapes, oak, and a touch of funk. Similar flavor with a little more of a sweet, citrus tartness. Florals, oak, more apples, and a nice funky brett. Finishes dry and crisp with a light bitterness and a touch of acidity. Lingers for a moderate duration after a light, refreshing body and lively carbonation. Overall, a nice sour. Not over the top, which I like. Definitely not the most complex RR Ive had, but well done nonetheless.

Draft at Monks for Russian River Day. Pours transluscent golden with slight trace of orange. Head is thin, small, and lacy. Aroma packs a nice floral wallop; dry hops, wort, wheat, honey, and crazy resin funk. Body is full and well carbonated with a somewhat dry, extremely tart palate. Finish is quick and powerful. Excellent sour ale.

Bottle, kindly shared by Kestral.  A dense, big-bubbled white head rising from a misty, pale gold colored body. A gentle, citrus-fruity sourness in the aroma. Also some well prononced Brett notes and tones of cellar and horsestable.  Taste is fruity. A fine, tart and sour fruitness, well rounded and extremely refreshing.  Green apples, lemons and lime come to mind, also a certain berry-ish astingency and a note of lactic acids and wood. Lingering sour-fruity ending. Utterly refreshing, high drinkabilty.

Special thanks to ygtbsm94 for sharing this gem.  Golden yellow, white creamy head.  Sour green grape and citric zest aromas warm to soft swirls of funked buttered oak.  Fresh lemony sour grape and lactic-wood flavors ride undercurrents of bretty funk and musty tart apple throughout.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation, light sour funk finish.  A beautiful beer

375ml batch 003 bottle from moejuck...thanks Joe! - Pours golden amber with a small white head. Oak, apple juice, lemon funk, pineapple, and the brett lingering in the background all earthy. The chardonnay is present too, mixing nicely with the fruity funk. Really tart--orange rind, oaky chardonnay, and butter, but transitions into some sweet grapes, until getting tart again on the finish. Dries the inside of your mouth with a tannic, wine-like dryness and an unripe lemon taste. Wonderful in the mouth, and a fantastically sour and tart. The brett is present, but not overpowering. What a fantastic beer!

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2010 On tap at OBriens (San Diego, CA): Pours hazy golden yellow, amber highlights, and a tight white head. This is my first sour and it didnt dissapoint. Aroma of Juicy Juice grape flavor, green apple, barnyard funk, fresh wheat ,and Chardonnay. Tart flavor, like a lemon warhead with white grapes and a nice doughy feel. Drinkability: Delicately tart. Pairing: Tangy cheese, fried dishes, or a light fruit dessert. Rebuy: Yes. #281 on 19022010, DG.

batch 03

Just popping from the cork, my nose is greeted with big whiff, reminding me of funky fresh goat cheese, with a light lemony zest in the background. It foams just to the top of the bottle, barely breaching the surface. Poured into the glass it has a big bone white head, with fair retention and some lacing. The taste is amazing, its very tart and dry with a nice citrus background. the finish is impeccable full of oak and butter, really drawing out the california chardonnay from the barrels. The buttery finish makes an odd sensation on the way down, but other that its very fizzy and very drinkable!

The first sour of my San Francisco trip and one of the best. Loved the simplicity of it, the freshness, the fizz, the clean and smooth body, the lightness, a lemony bite, a peppery kick and the sourness. The oak flavour adds an amazing depth to the beer. I just wish Id brought myself a bottle of this home to drink!
Draft, Russian River. Pliny the Younger 2010 release. OUt of a tulip, another great brew by RR. Excellent sour ale, lots of tarness, you can taste the brett

Pours golden with white head, aroma is champagne, acid funk and a hint of citrus.  Taste is wonderful, lemon, oak, champagne with a nice sour funk that isnt too overpowering.  Can drink this all night, terrific sour!

A: This one was explosively carbonated. A slight twist of the cork sent it flying through the air and to the ceiling. The beer itself is slightly hazed and straw colored with a fluffy white head.

S: The nose is not as overly "green" and tart as the servings of the newest batch have been. A nice level of Brett funk and dryness goes well with some tannic oak and a slight lactic and green apple tartness.

T: The flavor also is a bit heavier on the wild aspects and really has a nice mustiness to it. The tartness is not overpowering but provides a nice level of acidity and fruit (grapes, lemon, and apple).

M: The body feels a bit fuller than the newest batch, but that could be the high level of carbonation. The finish is nice and dry.

D: This batch seems to be quite superior to the newest batch and I see why people rave about Temptation so much. Great flavors and a really crisp, dry, and refreshing beer.

750ml body, thanks scrizzz! Pours a pale hazy golden yellow with a big coloumn of bubbles rising towards the big creamy white head which leaves much lacing as the glass is emptied. Aroma is of lemon, apples, cheese and barnyard funk. Just the right level of sharpness. Gloriously sour with lemon and green apples, before a quick stab of a raw bitterness, as from cranberries, lingon berries or red currants. It finishes slow with a funky, sweeter finish. Quite dry, light bodied with sparkly carb, which fits this beer perfectly. Endlessly refreshing and drinkable. Really enjoyed this.

Bottle, Batch 001 at the Grey Lodge Pub.  Looks like an aged white Bordeaux white, with dark yellow color.  Fruit and acid that kicks in in the beginning. Grape, green apple, and oak... A lot of acid and sourness.  THe body is on a ligher side creating a miss match with the oak and high acid.  I wonder if the oak used was a new oak or a used oak (which is preferable for a beer like this).  Tasted like a while wine that went through a second fermentation in the bottle.  Nice complexity on the nose, and pretty exciting.

( 750ml bottle batch 4x2 thanks to BA piclee) Pours clear yellow with great head and nice lacing. Nose of funk, yeast, wet wood, and cherries. Taste is very sour cherries, sweet tart candy, Belgian yeast, and muscat grapes.
UPDATED: JAN 21, 2010 On tap at russian river, complex palate cider dominates.  Raisin, apple, and alcohol notes.  Not my cup of tea, might have to get used to the style.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2010 Pours straw colored, opaque. Aroma of grass and brett funk. High carbonation pairs nicely with medium to mild sourness. Tastes sour with grass and citrus. Drinks clean and delicious.

Pours a slightly cloudy yeasty orange with a fluffy white head.  The lacing and resilience is significant, and makes for a beautiful presentation in a tulip glass.  Bret, chardonnay, sour vinegar, dough, and pixie sticks predominate the nose.  Some skunky rotten eggs in the background, but it is dominated by the delightful sour front.  The sour bitey vinegar flavor explodes on the tongue and instantly causes my entire mouth to water.  When I was rating this beer, I required a few seconds to catch my thoughts after not having a quality sour in many many months.  The bitey acidic palate makes a perfect match for the amazing flavor and aroma.

Bottle courtesy of thirdeye11.

Batch 4. Pours golden yellow with a white head. The aroma is very tart, with some vinegar and citrus. The flavor is tart, with lemons and a floral quality. A little bit of funk but not too much. Very drinkable sour. I had heard a lot about this beer and it didnt disappoint.

Batch 3, 2009 vintage.

Slightly hazy yellow color with orange hues. A pretty big ivory-colored head leaves some lacings.

A nicely sharp smell full of character. Funky horse blanket and aged cheese. Lots of tart fruits (apples, pears, lemon) and general notes of berries. Notes of fermenting apples as well. Light hints of oak barrel and a nice touch of alcohol in the background. A very impressive smell.

The taste is semi-sweet at first, but then turns rather tart. The tartness isnt really mouth-wrecking, but feels genuine and robust. A wonderful combination of pleasant fruit aromas (green apples, gooseberries, lemon) and funky notes of barnyard and mud. A hint of wood. Nice bretty flavors. In the finish, theres a mild grassy bitterness, sweet and phenolic alcohol, a gentle leafy hop note and a dry tartness.

With the last poor (I let all the yeast go into the glass) the beer changes character a bit. The tartness is muted and notes of vanilla and nuts develop.

Light body with a refreshing cider-like carbonation.

A very good wild ale. This one could probably go head to head with some of the milder Belgian gueuzes. Very refreshing and enjoyable. Impressive.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

750 mL bottle courtesy of scrizzz. Thanks! Pours a hazy lemon yellow color with a medium creamy head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma is tart and dry with citrus , white grape, peppery notes, caramel, funkiness. Taste is a nice easygoing mildly funky tartness with lots of dry citrus notes, green apple, red apple, and a tad bit of vinegar. Medium bodied. Very nice easygoing sour ale.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2010 bottle. aroma is complex with notes of peaches, lactic acid, slightly rubber brett, and strong fruit/spice esters. golden and totally clear with amazing lacing from a bright white head. flavor is amazing, tons of fruit tones with strong but still somewhat restrained sourness and beautiful barnyard funk. bone dry. immensely enjoyable.

Pours a slightly bronzed yellow with full white head. Aroma of lemon, brett, sour cherries. Flavor of lemon, raisin, white grapes and oak. The finish is tart with a bit of funk, but theres an off bitter, soap-like quality as well. It ruins an otherwise fine, albeit more subtle than I expected, sour. As an addendum, I left the final 4 oz in the fridge, unsealed, a drank it 2 days later. I actually enjoyed it a bit more with two days of breathing: it had gone a bit flat of course, but the unpleasant bitter notes were almost completely gone and replaced with more white grapes.

750ml I brought back from my trip to LA. Shared with my brother tonight at dinner. Pours hazy golden yellow with nice tight white head. Aroma is grapes and chardonnay. Flavor is tart with hints of lemon, wood, and white grapes. Finishes tart but not over powering. Really complex and delicate. Reminds me a lot of chardonnay. My brother loved this and he really isnt into craft beer and never had a sour before. This truly is a wonderful beer.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2011 750mL b3 shared with the family for Christmas. Poured into champagne glasses. Pours a glowing bright yellow that is cloudy with yeast and a decent size white head that has good retention and leaves sheets of beautiful lacing. Aroma is chardonnay, white grapes, champagne. Taste reminds me of a geuze minus the barnyard funk. At first there is a nearly mouth puckering sourness that overwhelms the palate for an instant. Then it goes from sweet to sour to bitter dryness back to wet sourness in all of about three seconds. Woah. There is some hop bitterness that reminds you this is a wild ale and not white wine. Was loved by all the wine lovers in the room. A big hit. Would be an excellent gateway beer to move someone from wine to beer snobbery. 12/27/2009 8/5/8/5/16=4.2FULL VERTICAL TASTING375mL b1. First batch of Temptation has gained quite the phenolic, plastic nose. The body is not too sour but rather sweet with minimal tartness. Finish is very dry. This batch isnt aging so well.375mL b2 pours with much higher carbonation and a gorgeous head. Aroma here is such spot on: cotton candy, funk, chardonnay, white grapes. Excellent body with some spicy sourness, sweet tropical fruits, candy. Very nice. This is the best batch by far.375mL b4 pours with a giant head. Nose is losing complexity with sweet vanilla and birthday cake. Taste is watery, much too sweet. Either too young or just not up to par.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2016 Fresh wood and tart lemon notes with a bit of licorish in the aroma.  Pale gold, like unfiltered honey appearance with solid white head.  Tart lemon with winey-woody notes and a very slight licorish flavor.

 Notes: 09 GABF/15 GABF Week

golden pour is hazy and a gusher.  healthy pillowy head.  Aroma is fruity floral and some tartness, Very tempting.  Nectarine is very prolific.  Light mouthfeel, very crisp.  Flavor is tart with some light fruitiness, some earthy floral notes as well.  Delicious

Bottle fizzed over upon popping the cork. Pours a cloudy apricot with a vigorous bubbly head. Aroma holds peach, mandarin orange, vinous notes, wood, and some light funk, though not powerfully tart in any sense. Flavor is really nice, with more fruity and woody notes. Its certainly evident that the wine barrels were of a white, rather than red- beautifully light and refreshing in flavor, particularly for a sour ale. Palate is medium bodied, but with a very drinkable finish. Really solid sour from Russian River.

Thanks craftycarl21! Hazy peach pour with a huge fluffy white head. Aroma is quite evident even before the first sniffs were encountered. Upon the actual delve, the aromatics present in floral, fruity brett funk notes. Lots of nectar, acidic citrus, and grapes. Oak, perfume, and yeasty dough round out the subtleties. Flavor is bursting with sweet nectar fruits, chardonnay, grapes, angelfood cake dough, mild acidity, and tart citrus. Oak and funky yeast notes come out further as she warms. Palate is super effervescent with a pillowy mouthfeel and a dry, clean finish. Another breathtaking sour for the nights festivities.
Bottle courtesy of thirdeye11. Batch 4. Hazy golden pour. Tall foamy head. Smell has easy flowers. Taste isnt too tart but definitely has a sour element. Sour bitter finish.

Sample at the SLC tasting 12/11/09 (batch 004) 
Appearance: Pours a hazy blonde with a small white head 
Aroma: Sweet, floral, yeast and citrus 
Taste: Sour apple, fruits with some wood flavor

My 777th rating and my last as a single guy. Wedding 12/11/09. ohh man this was a treat. Pours a cloudy fizzy golden color with a good looking white head. Aroma is sour funky goodness. Flavor is sour, funk, grapefruit and the sourness is very nice. Wow, this is an amazingly complex brew.

On tap at Capones.  Pours a clear golden yellow.  Not much head at all and no lacing.  Aroma is sour but fairly mild.  Taste is about the same, sour but mild.  A great blend of grapes and under ripe grapes.  Goes down way too smooth.  I could drink this all day.  Sour but not too sour.  Mouthfeel is fairly light, like a blond Belgian.  Great beer all around.  I had it in a 9 oz snifter but could drink much more.

appearance is a murky golden with three finger head and excellent lacing. Nose- sweet white grapes, lemon rinds. Taste- champagne like carbonation, blast of white grape sharpness and green apple sourness. Has a wood/ mineral like dryness to the finish. Really dries out the mouth. Having had the previous two batchs, the brett is definitely more prounounced each time out. Great stuff

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2011 Pale yellow tall white head. Aroma is briney and sour. The flavour is almost sickeningly sour. Long dry finish, and very slty. Interesting, but im not sure i would drink it again.

Well im drinking it again and i like it better. but unlike my first rating im finding it a little lacklustre instead of over the top sour. i am giving a it a few more points but it is more due to my development of palate since the last time i drank it. nice brew.

From bottle : Ive been waiting for this.  Pours a light golden color, with tons of bubbles, and a massive head.  Tons of lace around the glass as the head slowly falls.  Sour aroma with some grassy hops.  Taste is fantastic.  Crisp at the beginning with a sour middle.  The end fades very well into a very nice aftertaste.  Medium body with some carbonation.  Again, the finish is very nice.  I love sours....and this baby didnt disappoint.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2009 1. Cask Stillage from the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 26/09/2009
Big sour aroma. Golden coloured sour and hoppy with a crisp and slightly dry finish.
2. From the Bottle at the Falling Rock Tap House, Denver 26/09/2009
Sour fruit aroma. Golden coloured slightly hazy in appearance and sour. Smooth on the palate with a crisp and slightly dry bourbon finish.

Bottle sample from FoBAB.  Pour is lightly hazy yellow with a fairly large white head.  Aroma is acidic, lots of wood, chardonnay, brett, and some grassy notes.  Flavor is bretty/ funky up front with the woody chardonnay notes coming up  shortly after that.  Really thin mouthfeel, at least compared to DDG which I had just tasted.  Solid sour, but a little thin and not quite as much complexity as I was hoping.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2011 rating #900.  Bottle from trade with wavers1- thanks!  batch 004x1.  pours a hazy golden yellow with a white head.  leaves some decent lace.  Aroma is  lemon, grassy hops, herbs, pear, some light funkiness.  flavor is lemon, grapes, bread, musty basement. beers dont get much more crisp and refreshing than this.   Im not a big fan of blonde ales in general, but this is awesome.  extremely well balanced.  just an all around well crafted beer.  Russian river is tight. I gotta move out to santa rosa!  



rerate.  another batch four bottle.   consumed 2.22.11.   soft, herbal, lemongrass, and lactic acid in the nose.   some musty wheat.  almost berliner weiss-esque.  beautifully made.   awesome balance.   super pleasant earthy lemon, grass, lactic sourness.   some oak.   awesome beer.   sheesh.

Bottle courtesy of tampabrew. Pours a hazy yellow color with thin white head. Aroma is sweet and floral with notes of honey, citrus, vinegar, overripe cherries, yeast, some hints of caramel and grass. Flavor is about the same. Medium body with a fruity finish.

Straw body laced with moderate-high carbonation. Sweet yeast zest, slight mild acidity. Creamy with a hearty bread malt component. Light woody notes with a nutty essence.  The tartness highlights a Brettano-character which is prominent on the finish.  Great drink off tap @ M&V.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2014 Batch 4X2.  Pours clear golden, with a lasting two-finger cream-colored head, fine lacing.  Citrus, grass, pineapple aroma, very yeasty, with green apple, caramel and farmyard undertones.  Medium body, zesty and very tart.  Very fruity with flavors of sour apple, orange, and lemon, some spice and biscuit.  Light grassy finish, moderately dry, champagne-like.

Batch 05x1E. Pours clear orange-gold with a medium off-white head, very fine lacing, excellent retention. Very fruity aromas, mostly grape, a hint of cherry, biscuit, and grass. Light-medium body, velvety smooth. Lightly sweet, medium-strong tartness, just a mild suggestion of bitterness in the finish, but mostly lingering champagne flavors.

Pours a clear amber color with thin white head. Aroma dominated by tart oak character and light fruit. Soft carbonation up front with a huge oak flavor that is balanced by nice light fruit flavor. Hints of grape, cherry strawberry throughout. Creamy medium-bodied.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2010 Tap @ Belmont Station...  Poured a vibrant golden with a thick, white head that retained a decent size throughout enjoying this tasty beverage.  Aroma was wildly funky and yeasty with fruits and spices.  The Bret was brilliant in this one.  Palate was perfect with that usually dryness from a sour and was very refreshing.  Flavors of grains and lots of fruits -- lemon citrus, very sweet with spices -- almost like anise.  This beer was like liquid candy, bretty and tangy.

Pours a straw yellow color with a rich soapy white head.  Aroma of lemon, funk, and yeast.  Flavor is tart, funky, with vinous, sour and hints of oak in each sip.  Another high end offering from Russian River.

Courtesy of TampaBrew. Pours hazy dirty sand with thin white head. The aroma has white grapes, a touch of lemon, some mild notes of hay, malts, grains and some sour and tart notes. The taste is thin, fresh, and crisp with some grains and malts moving into light color skin grapes and then tart notes. I get some acidity and tartness heading into the finish as it evens out and comes to the end of the taste.

Thanks to TampaBrew for sharing this one.  Pours hazy yellow with a white head.  Nose is vinegar, light malt, tart citrus, lemon, and brett.  Flavor is similar with lots of citrus and vinegar; also a tart wine barrel presence.  Medium body beer that lingers with brett and tart.  These guys are the the masters of Sour Beers.  Good job, Vinnie.

Bottle shared at Moosetoberfest 09. Poured a hazy golden yellow with a smaller fizzy white head. Aroma is great with lots of sour fruity funky notes, lots of sour peach and apricott. Mediu bodied with very very lively carbonation, some champagne characteristics from all the carbonation. Flavor was slightly vinous, awfully sour, slightly funky and fruity and a hint of oak. Really nice stuff, nah this is great stuff.

Batch 3 bottle.  Huge cork pop.  Strong amber with big, dense white head.  Nose is beautifully sharp.  Wine and light funkiness on the nose.  vinegar tartness hinting behind.  Im already salivating.  Super sharp tart citrus.  Light and dry.  Grapes, lemon,  champagne-like. Maybe cherry?  Dry bitter finish.  Leaves earthy funkiness.

Served on tap at Obriens TION night in a 13oz Chimay.

Ive had this in bottle (batch 003) on several occasions, and found that I didnt enjoy it on tap as much. The oak comes through, and the beer really lives up to its description (is it a beer? is it a wine?). Blonde in color, big white head lacing. Medium sourness, tart fruits, oak, lemon come through. Medium bodied, dry, refreshing. Very good.

On tap at Falling Rock.  Pours hazy yellow with nice white head.  Aroma of sour grapes, funk, fruit, oak.  Pretty awesome aroma.  Flavor is a nice prickly sour.  Tart grapes, light funk and oak.  Dry finish.  Absolutely thrilled I got to drink this one.

On tap at the brewpub.  Great way to end the tasting of some great beers at a good brewpub.  The smell is heavenly, tart, fruits, complex, brett, wood, wine.  The look has a lacy off white head and is golden orange in color.  The taste brings back all the fun from the smell and ends nice and dry.

375 ml bottle (batch 001) via trade with Irishboy - Pours a hazy golden color with a 1/2 finger thick white head.   Very light lacing.  Has a light, but musty ripe fruit aroma with a faint hint of oak.  No tartness in the aroma!  The flavor is slightly tart esters with a little bit of malt sweetness.  Fairly mild compared to some of the of Sours Ive tried.  The tartness lingers a tad on the palate.  Medium body.  A pretty nice Sour.  Maybe I should age all my Sours for 3 to 4 years before drinking.  Thanks Richard.
Bottle from Lonehill. Appearance cloudy golden color with a 2 finger nice head. Aroma and taste of white wine, fresh fruits, some nice sour balance. Very good pallet, very enjoyable brew.

Pours a hazy straw yellow with a quick climbing head. 
Nose is very bright with lemon and yest, almost like a saison with brett. 
Taste is all over the place in a good way, light in body, extremely dry, nice light oak tanins, lemon zest, brett, leather, acid, apple peels, all compete for the palates attention, all find a way to be harmonious. It almost feels like this beer got lucky, shouldnt be this good, but it really is.

Bottle, thanks to TampaBrew for sharing.  Poured a hazy blonde color with a tall whispy white head that leaves good lacing on the glass.  Very vinous nose with notes of oak, brett, spice, and light citrus.  Medium body with a smooth mouth feel.  This beer rocks, dry and slightly acidic with lots of brett and oak notes throughout.  Good amount of tartness and earthiness with notes of grapes and spice.  Excellent.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2009 sample from the pitcher at GABF on 9/26/09... a light golden color with a white head... big Brett nose with some barnyard funk and tart apple notes... medium body... nice carbonation... sour finish... with a bit of oak.  really nice sour.

Courtesy of Philippe (Bov); corked bottleCloudy deep blond color; medium head. Aroma of vanilla, sweet wood, American yeast, light sourness. Smooth mouthfeel, good combination of astringency and sourness, with delicate vanilla/oak notes, The final is woody and lightly sour. Everything is very well combined. Excellent.

Pitcher pour at 2009 GABF. Pours a thin head, over a pale hazy yellow (SRM  2-3) body....nose is Brett like with sour acids, barnyard funk, bit of sweet fruits, grapes, apples, bit of cherry....taste is similar with all the Brett layers, finishing with a mild bitter finish.....mouth feel and carbonation were both medium. I am not sure what I think of beer aged in a wine barrel. Some I have tasted work, as this one did, some did not. I think the Brett is what made this attempt go. Tasting of 9/26/09.

On tap at Falling Rock. Pours a fizzy hazy yellow. Nose is lemon, lactic sourness, some mild grapes, white wine, sour apple. Flavor is a sharp acidity followed by a woody dry chardonnay flavors and sweet fruits, slight brett. Finishes dry and insanely easy to drink.

750ml bottle from Bman1113VR, thanks Andrew! Pours a nice deep gold with a frothy white head. Tart cherry, grapes and wine barrel aroma. Smooth tart malt body, oak, chardonnay and a light fruitiness come through in the taste. Imminently drinkable, like a fine wine. Delicious.

Tasting at GABF. hazy yellow color with white head. Apart from appearance, keep wine away from beer. At least for me, its just not doing it. The chardonnay taste ruins brew. very dry with sour grape nose and flavor. Also yeast flavor ruined by wine.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2009 Pours a cloudy hazy pale yellow color with a thin head on top.  The aroma is extremely sour smelling with sweet cherry fruity flavors coming through.  There is also a decent amount of a funk coming through in the nose as well with a distinct alcohol smell.  The flavor profile is insanely sour and sweet.  My taste buds were doing summersaults, not knowing for sure what to expect next.  Again, much of the aroma came through in the taste with sweet fruits and a definite alcohol character.  The finish was nicely dry and enjoyable.  Very nice.

Nice hazy golden with a small with foam leaving great lazings on the wine glass. Aroma is brett, lemon, barnyard, apples and wet hai with some nice oaky vinousity. Flavour is fruitjuicy and lemon-like, fresh, lightly funky with notes of vinous berries, oaky with fruitsugar. Ends on a dry ciderlike vinous note. The body is clean and smooth with finebubbled carbonation. Lovely mixture between a light blonde, a funky sour and wine.
Bottle gift. I think it was a gift from Capones. Hazy yellowish pour with generous white head. Cherry and apple aroma, Sweet in flavor(Not my style but not horrible.) For this style it was amazing.
500mL pours a nice golden with small head. aroma is vinous with some Brett. very nice lemon pucker with some vinous notes that complement well.

BEAUTIFUL beer. Pours a slighty hazed  burnt orange with a billowy head that settles to nice lace. Cant stop smelling this one. Sour peach, light funk. Chardonnay dryness ot this flavor, melon, peach, fruity and wonderful.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2010 I felt the need to re rate this since my appreciation for sours has grown since I first rated it. I sampled a batch 4X3 bottle side by side with a batch 3. Batch 3: Pours golden orange with a beautiful white head. Lots of streaming bubbles. The aroma is very tart and cheesy with horseblanket, grapefruit, lemon, and vanilla. I could be wrong, but I pick up slight notes of oxidation after over two years in the bottle. Some hint of sherry and nuts. Not overpowering or in any way spoiling the experience. The depth of flavor and funk is unmatched in this one. A great experience and one of the best and most interesting sours Ive had. 8:4:8:4:18= 4.2

Batch 4X3: Pour is similar to batch three, only the color is slightly lighter orange. The aroma is lemon, orange, subtle oak. The flavor is grapefruit zest and mild notes of leather and cheese. When compared to the batch 3, it tastes more spicy and less funky. Definitely dry and tart, but with a hard to pin down spiciness, almost herbal quality. (oregano, coriander, white pepper, clove?) Very subtle, and I probably would not have picked this up on its own, but next to the batch 3 I definitely noticed subtle hints. 8:4:7:4:17= 4.0

Overall the batch 3 was more interesting and earthy, funky, but the batch 4 was brighter and probably a touch more sour.

draft @ Skunk Train 2009!  Great oaky funky aromas, citrusy, tartness on the nose.  Pours cloudy blonde with a thick white head.  Crisp vibrant tartness with citrusy flavors, apple skins, great level of sourness and just so easy to drink!  Excellent!
wake up! pours a shimmer gold .. . medium white bubbly headring .. . citrus and sweet and sour aromas . .. nice bracing bite, refreshing and very elegant. . a great sour quaffer!
On tap @ RR.  Pours a clear blonde color with a small white head.  Very tart, sour aroma, a bit of funky barnyard.  Very sour body, some woodsy flavors.  Tart, sour finish.  Stellar beer.
(draft). Clear gold color. medium white head. Moderate sour aroma. Sour flavor with light apple. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.

750ml bottle.  Astounding aroma, with funky, farmy yeast, floral notes, wood, honeyish sweetness, faint winey tones, grassiness and straw.  Light yellow color, cloudy, with a lasting, fine head.  Flavor profile is impressive as well, dry, very lightly winey, tart, woody, leafy and gently bitter, in turns.  Nicely refreshing palate, very light feel and moderate effervescence, body is medium.  Really nice!

750ml bottle from Bev4less in Santee. Pours a cloudy dark yellow with a big fluffy white head that clings to the glass. The aroma is overtly funky with sour grapes, hay, sawdust, spices and lemons. The flavor is complex and tart with granny smith apples, grapes, gingersnap cookies, thyme, white pepper and lemons. The palate is full and malty. The finish is long and extra dry with lingering sour grapes. Overall: A very tasty sour, well done RR.

Pours a light orange with a medium white head. Aroma is of sour fumes, white wine fumes, and fumes. Flavor is a little more elegant: The fruitiness here actually differentiates it from the other 500 Russian River sours. Other than that its just another sour. Medium body/mouthfeel. Overall good.

375 ml bottle - batch 2; glowing, hazy light gold; huge foamy white head settles quick leaving lace; apples, pears, oak, brett; sweet and mild sour; drinks dry and sweet with sour apples, mild funk, lemons and a bone dry finish; killer nose and lovely texture; perfectly sweet and never acidic; fruity sourness blending together



draft @ Brouwers Big Wood - cloudy light orange with thin white head; apples, oak and brett; absolutely crushed the deviation in a side by side, which seems to have temptation as part of the blend; not sure how fresh this keg was, but on this day it was without a doubt my fav sour; unbelievably good this day



750 ml bottle - batch 4; reasonably fresh as opened right after it hit the seattle market; big pop and thick eggy white head settles slowly; sour apples, grapes, oak and plenty of sweetness and brett; texture is soft, subtle and delicate; richness comes out as it warms; fruit goodness and bone dry finish from the brett; fresh is certainly where its at with this one IMO b/c you get that big burst of fruit before the brett takes over completely

Hazy gold in the glasss, nose is green apples, a little lemon, and a nice barnyard-y sourness. Taste is really complex alll t through - sour apples and grapes up front, melding really nicely into an earthy brett-y funkiness and a crisp lemon-pepper finish. Bottle didnt last through 4 rounds of my fantasy football draft. Well done, RR.

Bottle @ Monks Cafe, Philadelphia.  All I can say to this is WOW....Pours a hazy golden color (at least it looked that way in the low light) with noticeable lacing and a small white head.  Aroma is lemon, earth/grass notes, and a definite brett characteristic toward the end.  Taste is the same, with an incredible citrus/earth characteristic, a very tart finish (though not distracting), and a wonderful dryness throughout.  I think I got a little sweetness and an ever-so-slight bitterness in there - its so sublimely balanced and complex.  I love it, I absolutely love it, and I need to get more from these guys STAT.

Bottle shared by Chris at Ebenzers.  Thanks!  Pale hazy golden yellow with head and lace.  Lemon pixie stix and hoseballs and hay aroma.  Extremely dry sweaty horseballs hay mild leather throat-clinching tart dry finish.  Soft warm efffervescence.  Awesome.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2011 Draft at Pizza Port.  Clear yellow pour with a thin white head.  Woody sour aroma with citrus.  Very sour flavor, but not overpoweing.  Woody citrus notes with ahint of vanilla.  Very nice

courtesy of Greg Gaughan - pours a hazy orange colour with a little persistent white foam; aroma of almonds, vanilla and apple, slightly woody; some acidity, creamy mouthfeel and with a good malt body; fair carbonation; some residual sugars with more notes of vanilla and almonds - a superb beer

2009 Bottle, Batch 4 - Pours a translucent pale yellow with a large off white head...aroma is green apple, oak, lemon, tropical fruit...flavour is more subdued that other RR wilds, slightly vinous, massively oaky, tart lemon and the lightest spiciness that starts in the nose and has the most ephemeral presence in flavour...very tasty...

Out of the RR Sours that I have had thus far, this is my favorite.  Probably second only to Duck Duck Gooze as far as sours go overall.  Amazing beer.Pour is just fantastic. Insane head with perfect lacing over a murky golden liquid.

Smells of tart lemons, some other fruits, and a vinegary sourness.

Tastes just great, lemon zest, sour apple, a little wood. Another amazing beer from Russian River.

Mouth is relatively thin over high carbonation, this is where the beer needs to be.

Just a goddamn exceptional beer.

Powerful tart sour dry aroma, jumps out of the glass.  Hazy gold, strong white head.  Reminds me of gauze, both dry and soft, nearly medicinal.  I had forgotten about the chardonnay barrels and probably would have noticed it had I looked for it.  It doesnt swirl with complexity but its a great beer that I couldnt drink slowly.

Huge thanks to MrBunn for sharing this.Pours a decent head with a peachy orangey yellow color. Great aroma of sour peach, lemon, a hint of soap, and some wood. Taste is similar, but way better. Very lemony.......damn thats good stuff.

Bottle with thanks to Kan.  Pours a massive head with a little bit of cloudy gold liquid at the bottom of the glass.  Aromas are fabulous... a lot of sour and funk (lemons, barn, oak, maybe some white pepper or something, etc.)  Flavor is more of the same, with lots of oak and funk and lemon.  Its pretty light on the palate with lots of carbonation and refreshingness.  Yum!
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle, batch 003. Pours a very slightly hazy orangish gold, very fine bubbled white head, slight lacing. Aroma is right away bright and vinuous, almost champagne like, slight yeast notes. Flavor is tart, very wine like, soft and dry finish.
Tap @ hulmeville inn. This sour was great. Golden pour with substantial carbonation. Flavor is great although not overpowering, funky sour with nice aftertaste. Great beer worth the trip.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06.

Poured cloudy yellow color with a large frothy off-white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Medium to heavy citrus and yeast aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and lively carbonation and average particles. Medium to heavy sweet & sour flavor with a medium to heavy bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration.

I shared this with freinds and enjoyed the beer.
Draft: pours a hazy golden amber with a thin foamy white head, aroma of citrus and funky aroma, taste is very sour, citrus, and some oak, fairly thin mouthfeel.

Bottle. 
Pours with a hazy yellowish brown hue with a small white head that is mostly diminishing. 
Aroma is sour - citrus, wheat, pineapple, and some apples. 
Flavor has a fruity beginning and then is followed by a enjoyable sour flavor which I love!
Medium texture. lively carbonation.

pours a semi-hazy yellow-orange with a large white fluffy head, and very good lacing.

smell is of sour malt, fruit, citrus, a little floral, and some yeast.

taste is tart, apricot, citrus fruits, orange, a little woodiness, some granny smith apple, and some sour malt.

Several pints at the brewpub in Santa Rosa.  What can you say about this one?  Frankly, this is the sour beer that all American sours should be compared to.  Translucent, hazy, cloudy, yellow gold with a thick, foamy head.  The nose is really nice, lemons, yeast, earth, herbs, white grapes, sweet, tart, sour, strong, inviting.  Flavor is excellent too: wheat, grass, lemons, flowers, garden herbs, slight wood, earth, wine, oranges.  Finish is dry and funky.  There are beers out there with crazier flavors but none are this solid.  Well crafted.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2010 Batch 3.  375ml.  Courtesy of cloudskipper.  Golden color with a real thick off-white head and a nice foam remains on top until the last drop.  Wow, what a great aroma; champagne, brett, chardonnay, lemon, yeast, flowers.  Flavors are tart and sour with a wonderful bretty dry numbing.  Chardonnay and oak does show in the flavor with lemon, grapes, and a bit of funk.  What an amazing beer.  Kudos to Vinnie for brewing this and to Chris for hooking me up!  Batch 3 rating 4.8.

Batch 4.  Sampled on 10/15/10.  Bottle courtesy of mkade8883.  This pours a clear golden color with a big fluffy white head.  Good retention.  The aroma is full of white grapes and a bit of funk.  This definitely resembles a white wine.  Lots of tart white grape chardonnay flavors along with oak, bretty funk, straw and some pepper.  Not quite as sour as I remember from batch 3 with some sweet citrusy fruit mixing in.  Very refreshing.  I compared this to Sanctification tonight and Ill be damned I thought Sancty was a little better.  Batch 4 rating:  4.2.

Ratings averaged.

bottle batch 4 poured a golden apple color with a little ring of white foam. aroma has bright white grapes, sour funk, vinegar, oak, citrus zest, and plenty of bretty yeast. crisp mouth feel with nice full carbonation. flavor is initially intensely sour, vinegar, oak, crisp white grapes, and a nice countering sweetness. the yeast just blow this out, bitter citrus, and it finishes with a mouth watering dryness. this is my favorite of the russian river sours I have tried so far.

very acrid aroma, sour apple, bordering on vinegar with traces of wood.  pour was a murky gold color, the head went up in a blaze and left pretty much no lacing. the wine barrels really did a number on the flavor, creating a very dry taste that was basically just wood and brett...reminded me of a superdry white wine that was going bad.  i have had this before and remembered liking it more, but at this point, i wasnt a big fan
Poured from 9L bottle at the brewpub, RBSG 2009. Golden with medium white head that lingered. Nose of banana and grapefruit, sour taste, with dry finish and excellent mouthfeel.
Pours a golden color with very little white head to it. Has a smell of brett, grapes, and wood to it. Has a bit of a funk, wood taste to it. Has a sour bitter taste on the finish.

Tap at Naked City! I have not rated that many sours, so please forgive me. Pungent fruity and sour aroma. A slight brett like aroma as well. Nice aroma. Very pungent aroma. Translucent orange in appearance. Has a nize haze look to it. Wow, this sucker is very sour at first, but then mellows to a slight fruit/sour combination. A very smooth beer, and very tastey. As I said I am new to the sour stuff, so after some experience I will re-rate.

8/8/09 notes:  (on tap at Blue Palms.  Poured into snifter a brilliant gold and white gold color with a fluffy white head.  Aroma is an incredible oaky, funky, lemon tartness.  Flavor first hits you with lemon meringue, then settles into a blend of strong brett funkiness, faint wood hints and some fresh cut grass.  Acidity returns in the finish, lemon-lime for sure.  Perhaps the best part about Temptation is the palate, which remains buttery but clean throughout, just light enough so that the lemon flavors can emphasize a zippy quality, and smooth to show complexity.
Cloudy glowing Yellow color, lemony and very refreshing. Earthy and fizzy with a very strong palate. Bottle from JW77.

Bottle at JW77s.  Cloudy gold pour.  Very nice beer!! Bretty, lemony, grapes and oak on the nose.  Flavor is tart but not crazy vinegar sour.  Great mouthfeel.  I really love the lemony funk!  A bit dry on the finish.  NIce.

Bottle from Total Wine in Rancho Cucamonga.. Pours a light golden with a fluffy white head and lots of carbonation bubbles...The only thing I can pick up in the aroma is the brett. Makes the mouth water!!  Flavor was lemons and brett..Lots of carbonations.. Good stuff!!
